abstract.text: Inlroduction;; Mortality prediction in critically ill patients is an every day routine in ICUs. Our aim is to evaluate prognostic accuracy of SAPS II as compared with the predictive capabilities of its predecesor SAPS 1, and with the one of APACHE II, probably the most used prognostic method of the available ones. Patients and S~tting; 568 patients admitted in two medical-surgical ICUs of two Hospitals (III -A-and II -B-level) were consecutively admitted (A: 358 and B: 210 patients) and prospectively admitted in the study. Methodology: All patients outcome were predicted by SAPS I and SAPS, as well as APACHE II, using the worst values availables during the first 24 h of stay in ICU. For APACHE II diagnostic grouping according original description was also considered. In all cases, procedence, type of patient (surgical or not, emergency admission or not), sex, age, length of stay (LOS) and other epidemiological data were also collected. Mortality was considered at the end of the hospitalary stay. Non paired Student T test, Chi square test, and Regression methods were used in tha analysis. Overall performance of prognostic methods were compared by means of the calculation of the areas under ROC curves. Significative differences were associated to p < 0.05. Results; Mortality in the study was 21% (p NS A vs B) and there were not significant differences in LOS. SAPS I and SAPS II revealed significant differences in severity when studying A and B populations (p < 0.014 and p < 10 .4) and risk of death evaluation was greater in B population when using SAPS II. For the whole sample and at probability level of 50 %, accuracy of prediction was 83 % for SAPS I and 80 % for SAPS II. At probability level of 90 %, accuracies of prediction for both methods were respectively 79 % and 82 %.. When using APACHE II, accuracies were 82% and 80 %. There were not signinficant differences, at any of the considered probability levels (50, 70 and 90 %), between real mortality and predicted mortality when any of the three methodologies were utilized, Facing the evidence that SAPS II do not represent, in our population, predictive advantages in front of SAPS I, a regression equation has been developed between SAPS II and SAP I (SAPS II = 10.

body_text.text: Introduction: Hemoglobin (Hb) oxygen saturation (Sat 02) and lactate levels (L) in pulmonary artery blood are usually considered as adequate markers of tissue oxygenation, In septic processes, there is a mismatch between oxygen deliveryuptake-consumption in splachnic areas. Mesenteric ischemia could be the reason for inmunologic damage, greater incidence of nosocomiai infection and the MOF syndrome appearance. Objective: To analize the existing relations between SatO2 and L levels in blood coming from the splachnic area through suprahepatics veins (S) and the ones from pulmonary artery blood (AP) in order to detect early markers of mesenteric isehemia. Material and Method: 13 patients whose situation coped with Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS), under mechanical ventilation and in stable haemodynamic condition were included in the study. Floating balloon tipped catheters were situated both in pulmonary artery and in suprahepatic vein. Proper situation was assessed by fluoroscopic examination. Simultaneous blood samples were obtaines from S ( both balloon inflated -SH-and notinflated -SD-) and pulmonary artery. In these samples blood gases and Sat 02, biochemical parameters -L, amylases, bilirrubin and GPT-and free radicals production markers -MAD and CYS-, were analyzed. Results were analyzed by means of paired T test methods and significant differences were accepted if p < 0.05. Results: Seven patients died between days 7 and 8 after the study. SatO2 in SH blood samples were significantly lower in patients to die (p: 0.037), but these results were not found neither in SD nor in AP blood. Sat 02 SH [ SatO2 AP ratio was about 53 % in the group of non survivors and about 85 % in the survivors group. L was greater and pH lower in all the samples from non survivors. MDA was permanently higher and CYS constantly lower. Conclusions: SatO2 SH and SatO2 SH/SatO2 AP ratio, are both good predictors of mortality in patients with SIRS. Blood sampling with inflated balloon from S avoids contamination with mixed venous blood from inferior cava vein. To best describe the Italian ICUs from the structural, procedural and patients outcome point of view, in 1992, we designed a mutticentric study involving 114 ICUs within the country with the objective of: 1) describing the baseline charactedstics of a group of patients admitted to the involved ICUs, with particular interest for the patients' outcome either at discharge from ICU or within three months after hospital discharge; 2) describing the structure of the participant ICUs; 3) describing the volume and the intensity of the treatments delivered to patients during thief stay in the ICU. Data collection began on May 11th, I992 and was completed on July 11th, 1992 Patients enrolled were 5111, ranging between 6 and 120 patients for single ICU, More than 40% of the admitted patients entered the ICU coming from the Emergency Department, 30% from the Operating Room, 25% from general hospital wards and only the last 5% were trasferred from other ICUs. The mean age of patients was 54 years, with 39% of them older than 65. The reason for admission in tCU was: respiratory failure in 26%; neurologic failure in 11%, cardiovascular failure in 6%; combination of the above reason in 21%; monitoring for expected clinical instability in 36%. More than 40% were admitted with a co-existent chronic disease while the mean SAPS was 10.6, with the great majority of patients (76%) with a SAPS score below 15. The overall ICU's mortality rate was 26% which rises to more than 40% during the follow-up period. As for the treatment, 65% required mechanical ventilation, 43% arterial catheterization and 7% pulmonary artedal pressure monitoring. Regarding the ICUs involved in the project, the mean number of beds is 7.5 (range 3-18) with an average number of patients admitted in 1 year of 320 (range 89W41). The most frequent structure of ICU includes a single room with one bed together with other rooms with two or more beds (56%). However, single room alone (19%) and rooms with two or more beds with no single room (19%) are also present. We believe that these findings give an accurate view of Intensive Care in Italy in order to start further ad hoc studies addressing more specific issues based on solid evidence. The occurence of fever in a patient of intensive care very often leads to the removal of a central venous catheter which is most of the time sterile. The aim of this prospective study was to compare differential blood culture (DBC) and quantitative catheter cultures (QCC) for the diagnosis of catheter related sepsis. METHODS: During one year, 174 central venous catheters were inserted in 113 adult patients hospitalized in two intensive care units (surgical and medical). All patients had the same dressing protocol (conventional occlusive dressing with polyvidone iodine). Catheters were removed because no longer needed or suspected infection. Immediately before removal, DBC were performed with blood drawn simultaneously from the catheter and a peripheral vein. After removal, QCC were performed according to Cleri modified Brun-Buisson technique. RESULTS: Patients mean age was 51 (SD:20). Initial SAPS was 12.4 (SD:4,6). Mean duration of catheterization was 8.5 d (SD:4.5). 26 catheters were positive (14.9% of catheters, 23% of patients). Central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary artery occlusion pressure (PAOP) are traditional guides to fluid therapy in the ICU, since filling pressures are assumed to reflect ventricular volumes and tlence preload. Intrathoracic blood volume index (ITBVI) is a recently-available measurement comprised of the right and left heart end-diastolic volumes, and pulmonary blood volume.

To study the relationship of volume and pressure we compared cardiac output with cardiac filling pressures and with directly-measured ITBVI in 55 mechanically-ventilated patients (median age 56 years, range 16-22 years; median APACHE II 22, range 7-34; median risk of death 40.4, range 5.3-80.4) with acute circulatory failure. All underwent pulmonary artery catheterisation and a 4F fibreopdc, thermistor-tipped catheter was inserted into the femoral artery for the measurement of ITBVI (COLD System Z-021, Pulsion Medizintechnik, Munich, FRG), obtained from analysing femoral artery dilution curves following a 10ml bolus of chilled indocyanine green solution (2mg/ml) injected into a central vein, Measnrements were made over a period of 48 hours of acute resuscitation.

There was a wide range in filling pressure (median CVP 13 mmHg, range 3-28; median PAOP 14 mmHg, range 4-33) and cardiac index (median 4.51 l/min, range 1. 22-10.75 ). ITBV varied from 543 to 2385 ml/m ~ with a median value of 1059 ml/m 2. There were no significant differences between survivors and non-survivors for any variable. There was no relationship between changes in CVP or PAOP and changes in cardiac index. Changes in CVP and PAOP were also unrelated to changes in ITBVI. Changes in ITBVI correlated strongly with changes in cardiac index ( r a = 0.54, p = <0.01).

Unlike CVP and PAOP there is a close relationship between changes in ITBVI and changes in cardiac performance in this study. This suggests that ITBVI is a superior clinical monitor of cardiac preload. (ICU's) in patients with respiratory failure to mobilize secretions and redistribute ventilation [1] . Invasive bemodynamic monitoring is a common standard for the treatment of critically ill patients. Measurement of cardiac output (CO) using a Swan-Ganz catheter is still time consuming and of possible hazard for the patient. Thus an uncomplicated method of monitoring CO would be of benefit for the critieaI ill patient. We developed a new method for CO detection which requires a central venous injection of a cold water bolus and a peripheral arterial detection of the thermodihitiou curve. For this purpose we introduced a 1.5 F artery thermodilutioe probe (PV2021) of the PULSION Inc. Munich/Germany into the radial artery. The measurements and signal analysis were performed by the COLD Z-021 system oftbe same company [1] . Several improvements of the conventional detection algorithms were necessary to calculate cardiac output from the obtained peripheral signal. So a better compensation of the baseline drift, an improvement of the signal/noise ratio, and a multiple regression analysis of the thermal dilution slope were suppleraanted before the common integration of the temperature signal. As a reference a Swan-Ganz catheter (Edwards Swan Ganz, Baxter Healthcare Corp.) was introduced into the pulmonary artery and cardiac output was obtained simultaneously with the thermodilution method in usual manner. The relationship between pulmonary and radial artery thermal dilution CO was investigated in i4 patients of our SICU with septicemia. About 150 measurements of CO with different probe sizes were undcrtaken in a range of 4.0 up to 15 L/rain. The results show a good linear regression of the CO values for a 10 ml probe with a temperature below 16 °C (r=0,978). The algorithm was good enough to detect a deficient signal/nolse ratio or a baseline drift. So a measurement was rather rejected than was a fault value calculated.

The new method allows a routine measurement of CO with a leas invasive expense. There is no need for a proper placement control of the catheter, the method can be used without time consuming, even pedoperatively. Due to the peripheral registration no dependence to the respiratory circle was registered. Since the cannulation of the radial artery and a central venous tine is at present a common standard on an ICU the precise measurement of CO can be performed on every patient without any additional hazard. The HELLP syndrome (H=hemolysis; EL=elevated liver enzymes; LP=low platolets) complicates about 10% of all eclampslas and occurs in approximately one in 150 to 300 births, After delivery there is progressive resolution in more than 900 of the cases, but 5-7% develop a "complicated HELLP syndrome" with high mortality that requires additional therapy. HELLP syndrome, thrombotic thromboeytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) share common pathnphysiological mechanisms like thrombotic microangiopathy, consecutive hemolysis and imbalance of prostaeyelin metabolism. Therefore, it seems reasonable to treat complicated HELLP syndromes with methods successful in TTP and HUS, Plasmapheresis -originally introduced in the treatment of TTP and HUShas been established in the therapy of HELLP. Prostacyclin infusions are successful in TTP and HUS; but there is littfe experience in the therapy of HELLP, We report about an extreme severe case of HELLP syndrome with multi-organfailure (MOF) including necrotizing pancreatitis and successful treatment with plasmapheresis and prostacyctin infusions. Case report: A 24-year-old woman presented in the 361h week of her firm pregnancy complaining of dark urine, leg swelling and right abdominal pain. Clinical examination revealed jaundice of the sclere, generalized edema and blood pressure of 170/120 mm Hg, Laboratory assays showed the typical constellation of HELLP with hemolysis (bilirubin 3,9 mg/dl; LDH 983 U/I; hemoglobin (Hb) 11,4 g/dl), elevated liver enzymes (GOT 227 U/t; GPT 184 U/I) and low platelets (39 O00lgt), despite of cesarean section clinical condition and laboratory values worsened, The patient deve]opped severe MOF with respiratory, renal and circulatory insufficiency, requiring meehanieat ventilation, dialysis and catecholamines. Additfanally, ultrasound and CT showed necrotizing pancreatitis which is mentioned as complication of TTP and HUS, but -so far , not of HELLP syndrome, in parallel the HELLP specific laboratory values worsened: bilirubin 8,2 gtdl; LDH 6220 U/I; platelets 22 O00/~l. Complicated HELLP syndrome was diagnosed and a therapy with daily plasmapheresis (exchange of 2 I of plasma against 1 t FFP and 1 I human albumine 5%) and continuous prostacyclin infusions (5 ng/kg x min) was started. After 6 days LDH, bilirubin and GOT were reduced to 1376 U/I, 1,9 mg/dl and 32 U/I, respectively, These values were in the normal range after an addRional week (excepted a mild elevation of LDH to 332 U/I). Platelets raised up to 487 000gl. Conclusions: 1.) Promacyelin infusions may be an improvement of plasmapheresis in the therapy ef complicated HELLP syndrome with two wellcome "side-effects": Inhibition of platelet aggregation with regard to extracorporal circulation and antlhypertensive effect with regard to hypertensive gestation. 2.) Like TTP and HUS, HELLP syndrome can be complicated by pancreatitis.

Introduction: With the increasing demands of contemporary intensive care medicine the traditional handwritten record has become woefully inadequate. New methods of data acquisition and data processing have to be employed to keep track of the current flood of data on the ICU, Methods: In June 1992 a commercially available, unix-based PDMS was installed on a 16-bed surgical ICU. The goal was a paperless documentation at the bedside. After 2 years clinical experience with the system two aspects were investigated: (a) Does the PDMS improve quality of treatment and care, and (b) is the PDMS cost-efficient? Results: The current implementation of the PDMS contains all parts of the patient record, including kardex, medication orders and plans of care, so that documentation is paperless at the bedside. 100% readability, automatic data transfer and calculations reduce the probability of errors. Documentation is more precise and more comprehensive; now an average of 350 out of 1000 available parameters are documented compared to a maximum of 140 parameters in the handwritten documentation. Statistical and retrieval functions facilitate an improved presentation of complex medical records and a rapid access to specific data. Automatic calculations, especially intake/output, and automatic data transfer result in time savings of up to 45 minutes per day per patient. Plan of Care and medication flowsheets provide standards for treatment and care, and provide the basis for consistent quality control. These tools also allow a more efficient use of the expensive resources of the ICU. On-line cost calculations for drugs and infusions are integrated in the I&O section. This allows accurate assessment of the effective medication costs for every individual patient. All patient data can be exported trite a secondary relational database and is available for complete accounting and for scientific research. The patient record is available at all places throughout the ICU and cannot be lost. It is also immediately available for later review and at readmission of a patient. Conclusion: Clinical information systems are commercially available and ready for clinical use on a broad scale. They can provide a major improvement in patient care and safety, without adding to the nurses' workload. Due to the increasing pressure of health care costs, expensive equipment such as CIS can only be justified if they can also be used for automatic accounting and costs analysis. POST-ICU DISCHARGE MORTALITY. Introduction: Intensive care is a relatively new and expensive specialty. Audit and evaluation of utilisation of existing ICU facilities is becoming increasingly important to ensure their proper use. ICU mortality rates alone are a crude measure of ICU performance. Increasing attention is being focussed on ICU readmission rates and it has been suggested that these may reveal problems with ICU discharge. We undertook this study to compare post-ICU discharge in-hospital mortality and ICU readmission rates in two ICUs with different sizes and different bed occupancy rates.

Methods: We retrospectively studied 799 patients (649 live discharges) from two busy European ICUs (ICU 1 = UK-8 beds, 401 patients and ICU 2 = Belgium-31 beds, 398 patients) and followedup all patients discharged from each ICU. ,Patients with a primary cardiac diagnosis, following cardiothoracic surgery, neurosurgery, transplant surgery and children under 14 years were excluded.

Results: There was no significant difference between the populations in mean ages, proportion of ventilated patients and mean ICU stay. Overall ICU mortalities were the samne (18.4% vs 19.1%). There was a significantly greater post-ICU discharge in-hospital mortality in ICU 1 (9.8% vs 3.5%, p<0.005) but with fewer 1CU readmissions (4.9% vs 7.5%, ns). Overall bed occupancy rates in the two ICUs were similar (63.8% vs 68.8%, ns) but at time of discharge for patients who died on the ward or who later needed ICU readmission, ICU bed occupancy rate >75% was significantly greater in ICU 1. Patients who died in the ward were significantly older, were more likely to have been ventilated and had spent longer in the ICU. Conclusions: ICU readmission rates and post-ICU in-hospital mortality rates may provide a basis for ICU audit and reveal a need for extra ICU facilities. We analyzed the disturbances of blood coagulation in 31 neutropenic patients with septic shock (white blood cells < 0,5x109/1). During our research of hemostasis we discovered rough abnormalities characteristic for Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIe). DIC was diagnosed by the criteria established by clinical symptoms and laboratory data. 74 % patients had a hemorrhagic syndrome. All patients had multiple organ failure. Significant promotion of soluble fibrin monomer level (more than 0,1 g/l) was noted in 70% patients. Prothrombin time was prolonged in 80% and antithrombin ffI was decreased in 60% patients. All patients had significant depression of fibrinolysis. Deep thrombocytopenia was in all causes and was closely related not only to depression of haemopoesis but also to consumption coagulopathy. The common principles of the DIC treatment in the neutropenic patients with septic shock included: replacement of thrombocytes; fresh frozen plasma transfusions; synthetic protease inhibitors. We noted a positive dynamics of coagulogical figures in survivors. We suggest that the DIC plays the important role in the genesis of multiple organ failure and haemorrhagic syndrome in neutropenic patients with septic shock. Introduction A relative ischaemia of the gastrointestinal tract has been implicated in the pathogenesis of Multiple Organ Failure, and hepatic dysfunction (perhaps secondary to ischaemia) may be a contributing factor. A dynamic flow-dependent test of hepatic function might permit the earlier detection of significant hepatic dysfunction which, without treatment, could contribute to increased morbidity and mortality.

In a prospective study of 27 critically ill patients (median first 24 hour APACHE II score 22, tCU mortality 44%, Standardized Mortality Ratio 1.03) with inadequate tissue perfusion we measured the hepatic metabolism of lignocaine to monoethylglycinexylidide and the clearance of Indocyanine Green over the first three days following admission to the ICU. These were compared with standard liver function tests and related to tonometric assessment of gastric irrtramucosal pH (pHim) and outcome.

There were no significant differences either in bilirubin, aspartate aminotransferase and alkaline phusphatase levels, or in ICG clearance between survivors and non-survivors. On day three the median MEGX level was significantly higher in survivors than in non-survivors (16 vs 2.4 ng.ml *~, p< 0,002). The median MEGX level in non-survivors felt over the three days (20.6 to 2.4 ng.ml% p< 0.002) but there was no significant change in survivors. MEGX levels were significantly correlated with pHim {Rs = 0.69, p< 0.001 ) as were the changes in the two measurements over the three days (Rs = 0.46, p<0,02). The MEGX formation test and gastric intramucosal pH were the most discriminatory with regard to death and survival.

Our findings suggest that critically ill patients develop significant hepatic dysfunction which is associated with a poor outcome. This is likely to be due to a mis-match between hepatic metabolic demand and blood flow and the MEGX formation test appears to be an extremely effective means of assessing liver function and flow in this group of patients.

Endotoxin shock in rats is characterized by a low output state, and leads to early renal insufficiency indicated by a low renal plasma flow (RPF) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) without an increase in filtration fraction (FF). In another form of shock caused by low venous return, in which RPF fell as much as in endotoxin shock, we found a compensatory rise of FF, however (van Lambalgen et aL Circ Shock 35,1991) . In a second group (BS; n=7) a balloon (below renal vein) was inflated in the vena cava (from t=30 to t=135 min) to cause comparable decreases in CO (50-60%) and RPF (70-80%) as in ES. A third group served as time matched control group (C; n=9). At t=135 experiments ended and the kidneys were fixed by perfusion (glutaraldehyde; via the abdominal aorta) at the prevailing mean arterial pressure, imbedded in methacrylate and ll, t sections the lumen of the proximal and distal tubules, the brushborder thickness and epithelial vacuolizafion were measured, using point or line matrices in 30 adjacent cortical high power fields at a 400x magnification. body_text.text: The clinical course of infections by serological group A streptococci varies from etysipel to the toxic streptococci shocksyndrome (TSS). The incidence of the latter is increasing, conditioned by more virulent stems. The mechanism of infection in TSS remains vague, probably streptococci, colonizing the skin as common flora, infect wounds, originating often from banal injuries. This may render the search for a focus more difficult. Fulminant septic courses are connected with increasing pathogen subgroups of streptococci, which can be determined by their M-and Tproteins. Especially M types M1, M3 and M18 are of importance in TSS, leading to a letality of 30 -50% (1). The sheckcascade may also be induced directly by the A and B toxins or streptolysin O, originating from streptococci. Until now, there are only few reports of septic courses after streptococci infections. Therefore, we demonstrate the case of a 28 year old male patient, who was transferred to our ICU in septic shock along with acute renal failure and ARDS. The cause for this TSS was an inconspicuous wound after a trifling trauma, leading to a necrotizing fasciltis of the right arm. Only by aggressive surgical proceedings, including amputation of the right arm and extensive dermatofasciotomia of the dght thorax, we succeeded in our intensive therapeutic measures to stabilize and improve the cardio-pulmonal condition. The patient could be discharged from our clinic one month later. Therefore, we emphasize the importance of instant interdisciplinary cooperation, regarding the microbiological monitoring for an adequate chemotherapy, and the surgical focus sanitation, which is a prerequisite for a successful intensive care therapy.

OSWALDO CRUZ GERMAN HOSPITAL-S&O PAULO -BRAZIL Clearance of vasoactive compounds during continuous hemofiltration in patients with septic shock RJ de Wit, IM Drenth, AJJ Woittiez Patients with multiple organ failure usually need circulatory support with inotropics and/or vasoconstrictors, often combined with teatment by continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVHH) for acute renal failure. One should expect that small molecules as dopamine (dopa), noradrenaline (nor) and adrenaline (adr), (M weight respectively 205, 189 and 182 Dalton) are easily removed by CWH. Dose adjustment may be necessary. No clear information on this subject is available. We undertook a clearance study in 6 patients (4 men, 2 women; aged 50-76 years). All patients received triple vaso-active therapy for severe septic shock and multiple organ failure and were treated with CVHH (16-36 liters/day) using a Gambro MPM 30 module and a FH-6hemofilter. One hour sieving coefficients for dopa, nor and adr were respectively: 0,52 ±0.21; 0,67 ±0,ii and 0,82 ±0,52. Clearances were 9,4 ±3,3; 15,2 ±2,7 and 16,4 ±8,7 ml.min, respectively. Conclusion: Seaving coefficients and clearances for vasoactive substances during CVHH were in the range of expected small-molecule clearances (compatible with urea and kreatinin clearances) and there seems no need for dosage adaptation in hemofiltered patients. Introduction: SIRS leading to multiple organ failure is known to be the major cause of delayed death after multiple injury. Cytokines and other mediators are involved in the development of SIRS, In part, this syndrome is eharacterised by a hyperdyuamic circulatory state and impaired oxygen utilisation. Hemofdtration is a welt estab/ished and safe treatmen~ in acute renal failure and has also been used in acute respiratory failure. There is evidence that early treatment of severe sepsis with haemofdtration may be beneficial, e.g. by elimination of circulating mediators. Because of the pathopbysiological similarity of infection-related and posttraumatie SIRS we investigated the influence of CWH on posttraumatic circulatory state, oxygen extraction ratio, circulating mediator levels and tissue injury.

Methods: 24 patients with severe multiple injury (ISS > 27, mean ISS 33,8) without intracranial bleeding or other contraindieations for modest heparinisation were involved in this prospective randomised trial with standard ICU-therapy. 12 patients received isovolaemic CVVH from day 1 mltil day 5 after injury with removal of about 500 ml filtration fluid/h. Cardioeimulatory and oxygen consumption parameters were measured and calculated by means of a pulmonary artery catheter.

Results: There were no major complicatinus related to CVVH. Whereas mean arterial pressure, heart rate, pulmonary wedge pressure and calculated oxygen consumption were not sigmficantiy different in both groups, there was a singnificantly less elevated cardiac output, less decreased systemic vascular resistence and increased oxygen extraction ratio in the CVVH-group. A variety of mediators, e.g, C3a, PMN-elastase, I1-6, were significantly reduced in CVVH group, indicating attenuation of SIRS. This was supported by reduced lipid peroxidafion products, suggesting limited membrane injury. No patient died in either group within a 30 days observation period, Conclusions: CVVH attenuated posttraumatie SIRS-associated hyperdynamJe response and improved oxygen extraction ratio. This may be beneficial espeeialIy for cardiopulmonary compromised patients. Furthermore, the results prwdde evidence for a reduced posttraumatic inflammation in CVVH treated patients. However, further studies are needed before CVVH can be advised for this proposal.

Haibo Zhang, Herbert Spapen, Panayotis Manikis, Peter Rogiers, Denis Schmartz, Jean-Louis Vincent Introduction Endotoxic shock is a representative "oxidative stress". Tirilazad mesylate (U74006F) represents a new class of substances with effective antioxidant properties.We studied the effects of U74006F on 02 consumption (VO2)/O2 delivery (DO2) relationships when blood flow was progressively reduced by cardiac tamponade during endotoxic shock in 24 anesthetized, mechanically ventilated dogs. Methods Group 1 (N=8) and Group 2 (N=8) received endotoxin (2 mg/kg i.v.) alone or combined with U74006F at an initial bolus of 80 #g/kg i,v. followed by an continuous infusion of 10 #g/kg.min, respectively. Group 3 (N=8) served as control. All animals were given saline infusion to restore baseline cardiac filling pressure. Tamponade was then induced in each dog. Regional blood flow in superior mesenteric, left renal and femoral beds was measured by ultrasonic flowmeter. Venous catheters were also inserted regionally. Systemic and regional VO2 was derived from the expired gases or calculated as the product of regional blood flow and the arteriovenous difference in 02 content. DO2 was determined as the product of blood flow and arterial 02 content. In patients with COPD pursed lips breathing (PLB) is known to reduce dyspnea and to improve gas exchange. These effects have been attributed to a decrease in small airway collapse. To study the principle of PLB in ventilated patients with COPD, we investigated the effects of an external resistance added to the expiratory port of the ventilator on respiratory mechanics. 5 patients who were paralyzed and ventilated in the volume controlled mode, were studied during unobstructed expiration and during application of an external resistance. The added resistance was chosen to lead to an external PEEP of 4 cm 1-120. In all patients intrinsic PEEP ~EEPi) was established during unobstructed expiration. The application of the resistance did reduce PEEPi-level; the total PEEP-level (sum of extrinsic PEEP and intrinsic PEEP) remained unchanged. Analysis of the expiratory volume displacement revealed that the added resistance did retard the expiration. Expiratory flow-volume curves revealed that compared with the unobstructed expiration the added resistance was associated with elevated iso-volume flows, indicating a reduction in the transpulmonary resistance. This reduction in transpulmonary resistance was probably due to the abolishement of expiratory flow limitation, which was demonstrated by the interrupter technique. Application of an external resistance added to the expiratory port of the ventilator can in ventilated patients ~$th COPD reduce transpulmonary resistance and abolish expiratory flow limitation, without increasing lung volume.

PA~ AND METHODS We studied 34 patients in which PDTwas perforraed using the technique described previously. The prospective microbiological follow-up methodology consisted inthe obtaining oftracheostomy stoma exudate specimens for culture the days 3, 7, t0 and t5 after the procedure. The area was previously washed with normal saline solution and the specimens were obtained of the inner part of the stoma. The quantity and quality of the exudata was also assessed and the presence or absence of active pneumonia (as defined by Maki criteria plus microbiological diagnosis through BAL and/or telescoping plugged catheter guided through fiberoptic bronchoscope) atthe time of PDT performance was considered. Criteria defilaing tracheostomy stoma infection included:
1) Obtaining of purulent-fetid stoma exudates. 2) lnflamatory signs at the stoma area. 3) Positive cultures of exudatos for bacteria considered responsible for the infection.

The underlying diseases of the patients studied were distributed as follow: 3 cardiac surgery patients with postoperative respirator), fallure; 6 neurosurgical patients (tumoral) with prolongd coma aRer surgery; 10 with severe head injury (GCS less than 6); 7 with spontaneous acute intracerebral hemorrhage; 4 with hypoxia-isquemia encephalopathy and 4 w~ other miscellaneous conditions. At the time of PDT, 17 (50%) had criteria of active nosocomlal pneumonia; in 12 of them a single bacteria wasisolated wbilcinthe other 5 patients, mixed infections wasdocumented. Tile most frecuentty isolated Garm positive bacteria was Staphilococcus Aureus (in 8 patients, being 3 of them resistant to methicillin). The most frecuemly Gram negative bacteria was Acinctobacter Baumanni (in 3 patients). Only 2 developed nosocomiaI pneumonia aRer the procedure, and the responsible bacteria was Serratia Mareencens and Enterobacter Cloacae. In none of the cases, the microorganism responsible the the pneumonia could be isolatad from the stoma exudate. We obtained the 4 programmed cultures in 25 of our patients. In 14, all the cultures was negative. The positive cultures were considered as contamination in all cases; 9 bring Glum positive bacteria and 2 Gram negative bacteria. None of this patients had criteria of stoma infection. CONCLUSIONS With the methodology exposed, stoma infection criteria could not be established in any of our 34 patients. The presence of nosocomial pneumonia in 50 % of the patients at the time of PDTperformance is noteworthy. Only 2 developed nosocomial pneumonia aRer the procedure in our serie. The results obtained are in agreement with the theoretical advantages of PDT which include; Minimal surgical scar, less tissue retraction, better stoma sealing around the tracbeostomy tube with better fixation and finally less hamorrhage incidence.

NO inhalation improves oxygenation in ARDS. This is supposed to be related to vasodilation of the ventilated zones of the lung, inducing a "pulmonary steal" of blood from low ventilation/perfusion ratio zones to correctly ventilated zones. A 64-year-old man was suffering from severe ARDS (Murray's score:3) related to a bilateral pneumonia. He was ventilated with 100% oxygen (PEEP: 10 cm H20). The next day, the patient was turned in PP, the improvement having been less than waited. PP was maintained during 6 h. Gas exchange characteristics are reported ( the first point was obtained after a 30 rain. stop of NO)
It is suggested that PP increases ventilation/perfusion ratio by recruiting hypoxic zones, with decreased ventilation, permitting at NO to reach new lung zones and to increase its effect.

An automatic system designed for periodically computing respiratory parameters fTom the tracheal pressure and flow curves provided by modern ventilators has been already described (6th European. Congress ICM, Barcelona 1992) . The aim of the present study was to evaluate the validity of respiratory resistance (Rint) provided by this monitoring system using the end inflation occlusion technique. A CESAR® ventilator (TAEMA TM) connected to our monitoring system was set in the controlled ventilation mode with constant flow inflations. It was connected via a conventional patient circuit, including an empty humidifyer (Model 3000 HPD Medical TM ), to a test lung (Model 2600i Dual Adult TI'L ®, Michigan Instruments~). The airway resistance was set at various levels using 8 different combinations of resistors (PneuFlo TM Airway Resistors). As the PneuFlo resistors exhibit parabolic pressure change as a function of flow, we first calculated the true resistance (Rtrue) corresponding to each combination at the imposed flow, The mean value of 5 consecutive automatic estimations has been obtained for each resistor combination (mean variation less than 5%) and compared to the corresponding Rtrue. There is a significant correlation between measured and calculated values (Rint = 037 Rtrue+3.5 cm H20.l-l.s, p< 0.05). The intercept corresponds to the resistance of tubings between the ventilator and the test lung. The slope is well explained by a model of compressibility of air in the humidifier. This slope effect becomes important in high lung resistance situations.

body_text.text: Self-extubstion may occur in intubated patients and may pose subsequent clinically relevant problems. The objective of this study was to evaluate the incidence and associated factors related to self-extubation.
body_text.section: INCIDENCE AND CONSEQUENCES OF ENDOTRACHEAL SELF-EXTUBATION.

body_text.text: Methods~ We prospectively studied all intubated adult patients admited in a general intensive care unit (ICU) over an eight month period. Patients were divided into two groups: deliberate self-extubation (DSE) and accidental self-extubation (ASE). We analysed several clinical factors associated with this complication.
body_text.section: INCIDENCE AND CONSEQUENCES OF ENDOTRACHEAL SELF-EXTUBATION.

body_text.text: Results: 293 adult patients were admited in our ICU of whom were intubated 184 (62.8%); of these, 15 patients presented 17 episodes of self-extubation (incidence 8.1%). Ten were DSE (58.8%) and 7 were ASE (41.1%), P: NS. Nine of the 17 episodes required reintubation {52.9%): 5 ASE (71.4%) and 4 DSE (40 %), P: NS. Five of seven ASE patients (71.4%) were receiving full ventilatory support, while the remaining two (28.5%) were being weaned. Six of ten DSE patients (60%) were receiving full ventilatory support and the remaining four (40%) were in the weaning period. DSE patients presented 1.2 points in the average Ramsay sedation scale as compared to 3.3 points in ASE patients, P: NS. There were no differences between ASE and DSE patients regarding age, sex, SAPS at the self-extubation or admitance day, or number of days of mechanical ventilation prior to self-extubation. Mortality rate was 30% in ASE, 28.5% in DSE, and average mortality rate in intubated ICU patients was 26%; P: NS.
body_text.section: INCIDENCE AND CONSEQUENCES OF ENDOTRACHEAL SELF-EXTUBATION.

body_text.text: Conclusion: Incidence of self-extubation in our ICU was 8.1%. DSE occurred predominantly in patients having a very low degree of sedation. Mortality seems to be unaffected by the episodes of self-extubation. The Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is eharacterised by increases in pulmonary capillary permeability and lung water. Fluid management is usually guided by measurement of the pulmonary artery occlusion pressure (PAOP) and the cardiac output.

All underwent pulmonary artery catheterisation and a 41= fibreoptic, thermistor-tipped catheter was inserted into the femoral artery for the measurement of EVLW (COLD System Z-021, Pnlsion Medizintechnik, Munich, FRG), which was obtained from analysis of the femoral artery dilution curves following a 10ml bolus of chilled indocyanine green solution (2mg/ml) injected into a central vein. Measurements were made over a period of 48 hours of acute resuscitation using our standard unit protocol.

body_text.text: The respiratory distress syndrome is an important cause of respiratory failure, and is associated with impaired surfactant function leading to atelectasis with severe hypoxemia. Application of exogenous surfactant, or increase in PEEP, increases arterial oxygenation by recruiting collapsed alveoli. Recently, it has been demonstrated that inhalation of nitric oxide (NO) can be used to produce selectee pulmonary vasodilatation leading to redistribution of the pulmonary perfusion followed by improvement of arterial oxygenation. In this study, we examined the benefits of inhalational NO in combination with surfactant therapy on blood gases in an animal model of acute respiratory failure. Methods: Adult New Zealand rabbits (n= 12; 2.7-+0.3 kg) were anesthetized, tracheotomized, paralysed and ventilated with a Siemens Servo Ventilator 300 (Siemens-Elema, Solna, Sweden). A new prototype of the Servo 300 was used, which was equipped by the company with an in-built computerized NO application system. After inducing respiratory insufficiency by lung lavage, animals were first ventilated for 45 mfn and were then randomly divided into three groups. The first group (n=6) received a natural surfactant (25 mg/kg) intratracheally. After 30 rain, different concentrations of NO (4, 8, 10, 16, 20 ppm) were inhalated for 30 min and blood gases were measured at 5, 15 and 30 min after inhalation. After each NO inhalation, NO was turned off for a period of 30 min and blood gases were measured accordingly. The second group (n =3) was not given surfactant but received NO treatment in the same way as group 1. The third group (n=3) received only suffactant (25 mg/kg). Results: In group 1, instillation of 25 mg surfactarrt per kg bw improved arterial oxygenation from 58-+12 to 302_+86 mmHg. Adding NO in concentrations between 4-20 ppm, PaO 2 could be further improved. After turning off the NO inhalation, arterial oxygenation decreased. There was no correlation between the NO concentration and the changes in artedal oxygenation. In group 2 (PaO 2 =63--10 mmHg), NO had no effect in improving gas exchange, independently of the NO concentration. In group 3 (PAO2=61 +-7 mmHg) arterial oxygenation increased to 280+-61 mmHg and decreased slowly over time.

The purpose of the present study was to determine the effects of varying levels of volume related PAV on breathing pattern and inspiratory effort. Flow, volume, esophageal 0%s) and transdiaphragmatic (Pdi) pressure were measured in 5 intubated patients with ARF. The level of volume related PAV was varied from 20 to 80% of respiratory elastance while flow related PAV remained constant at -75% of respiratory resistance. Results (mean + SEM) are shown below. Compared to spontaneous breathing (SB), PAV significantly increased tidal volume (Vv), mean inspiratory flow (MIF), and minute ventilation (V~) (*P<0.05) while respiratory rate (P,R) tended to fall. This was accompanied by a graded reduction in the pressure-time integral ( ~ P) of Pes and Pdi, both per minute and per liter Vr. In conclusion, volume related PAV can reduce inspiratory effort while improving breathing pattern in patients with ARF.

Complex technical device control in intensive care medicine -a work psychological analysis

One important requirement that the medical staff in intensive care have to fulfill as part of their every day work is controlling complex technical devices. The knowledge and learning demands in this domain are getting higher, as in the course of technical development increasingly more and more complex devices are used. This study investigates the cognitive and handling requirements of operating an intensive care device from a work psychological point of view. The concrete case studied is the control of respiration units,

The process of setting a respiration unit is differentiated into three component requirements: therapy planning (which basic kind of respiration therapy shall be applied?), action planning (how can the therapy plan best be realized on a specific respirator?), and plan execution (which manipulations of the user interface of the respirator do execute the planned actions?). It is analyzed how well the processes of action planning and plan execution are carried out in dependeace on three mare variables: type of device, type of task and degree of users' experience.

16 novice aud 16 experienced intensive care nurses solved four realistic control tasks on respiration units from two different technical generations ("Siemens Servo Ventilator 900C" from the older electronical generation, and "Puritan Bennett Series 7200a Microprocessor Ventilator" from the newer microprocessor geaeration).

Considerable deficits in the beginners were revealed if confronted with non-routine tasks and when working on tile newer, microprocessor controlled device. lmplicatiol~s of those results for operator training as well as for ergonomic improvement of devices are discussed.

Introduction: In patients with adult respiratory distress syndrom (ARDS) densities corresponding to atelectases and pleural effusions are observed in the dependent lung regions when looking to the thoracic computer tomography (CT) scan. To change patients position from supine to prone should redistibute and when atelectases are recruited, reduce the densities observed in the CT-scan and improve oxygenation. Methodes: After approvel by the local institutional review board 10 artificial ventilated patients suffering from severe ARDS (LIS > 2.5, Murray et al, Am. Rev. Reap. Dis.1988: 130: 12-15 ) were included to the study. In the initial thoracic CT-soan before starting prone positioning dorsal dys-and atelectases were present in all patients. The patients were positioned between supine and prone position in 12 hours intervalls, for an allover time period of 6 days. Thoracic CT scans were repeated at the 6th day after admission. Quantitative analysis of CT scan data was based on the frequency distribution of the CT numbers. The CT number represents the linear attenuetlon coefficient of a X-ray in a given substance relative to the linear attenuation of water, and is expressed in Hounsfield Units (HU). Recruitment of atelectases after 6 days of intermittant prone positioning were quantified by defining 3 compartments within the lungs: a)normal inflated, b) poor inflated, c) non inflated lung (Rosenblum et al; Radiology 1980; 137: 409) . The frequency distribution of HU in each compartment was computed at the carina level (C) and 1 cm above diaphragm (P). Gas exchange was assessed by aterial blood gas analysis. Data were statistically analized by using ANOVA. Can a shift from carbohydrate (C) to lipid (L) calories decrease the carbon dioxide production (VCO 2) in critically ill patients? 16 patients with an ARDS and total enteral nutrition were divided in two groups. 8 patients received during a period of 6 days an enteral diet with 50% of the calories as C and 8 patients with identical conditions a enteral diet with 50% of the calories as L. All other components of the diet are comparable. VC02, oxygen consumption (VO 2) and the carbon dioxide tension in the arterial blood (paCO 2) are measured and the respiratory quotient (RQ) as well as the APACHE II-Score and the Score ofELEBUTE & STONER are calculated.
Conclusions: Shifting from C to L calories in an enteral diet decreases the VCO 2 of critically ill patients (see RQ). This effect influenced the paCO 2 not significantly.

Methods: Nine female Yorkshire pigs (50 ± 3 kg BW) were anesthetised with a continuous infusion of ketamine and midazolam and paralyzed with pancuronium. All animals were surfactant depleted by lung lavage to a Pat 2 below 100 mmHg and randomized to receive either perflubron (n=3) or saline (n=3) in 5 doses of 5 ml/kg at 20 min intervals, or to receive no instillation (n=3). In all animals heart rate, mean arterial pressure, mean pulmonary pressure (MPAP), cardiac output, and arterial oxygen tension (Pat2) were recorded at 20 rain intervals (in the treated groups 20 min after each dose). Results: Perflubron resulted in a significant (ANOVA p<0.01) increase in Pat 2 from 88.3 ± 9.2 to 367.5 ± 37.5 mmHg. Whereas the other groups showed no significant increase in Pat 2, There was no deleterious effect on any hemodynamic parameter in the perflubron group, even the MPAP showed a persistent decrease (7 ± 3.6 mmHg) after the first 5 ml/kg of perflubron. Results and conclusions. See Introdu~: Prone position has been repeatedly recommended for the treatment of severe ARDS. Especially in patients with major ventilation/perfusion mismatch this method has a great appeal from a pathophysiological point of view. Therefore, we investigated the treatment of ARDS with prone position in patient without thoracic trauma.

Methods: 30 consecutive patients with severe ARDS (Murray-Score > 2,5; 16 pneumonia, 6 sepsis/septic shock syndrome, 3 post hemorrhage, 5 cryptogenic origin; 18 male, 12 female, mean age 62 years) were conventionaUy ventilated (pressure controlled ventilation, PEEP 6-10 mbar, I:E=I:I, Ppeak < 30 mbar). If after 24 hours palmonary fimetion did not improve patients were placed in prone position. Change from prone to supine position was done every 12 hours. Beside ultimate survival, parameters investigated were AaI~, PaOz/fiO2, and Qs/QT (23 patients with. Swan-Gaaz catheter).

In prone position 25 of 30 patients showed a dramatic improvement in pulmonary function. During the first 12 hours mean QS/QT decreased by 25%, AaDO 2 by 21%, and PaO2/fiO 2 increased by 26%. Changes were most pronounced in patients with high Qs/QT, and in patients with an onset of ARDS less than 48 hours before first application of prone position. After an average of 9 position changes (2 to t6) 22 of 30 patients could be weaned from tile ventilator. 20 patient could leave the hospital. Negative side effects were minor, including slight cardio-vascular depression and increase ia PaCt2, and never posed a limitation to continuation of prone position. Nursing and care have to focus especially on the prevention of skin lesions of exposed areas.

Conclusion: In this investigation prone position proved to be an efficient and safe method in the treatment of severe ARDS. Patients with a pronounced vemi/ation/perfusion mismatch and patients in the early stages of ARDS appear to profit most from prone position. Therefore, our study indicates that prone position should be among the first measures taken in the treatment of ARDS. Pulmonary toxicity is a well-recog~ed complication of Neomycin therapy. Discontinuation of the drug is followed by resolution of the inflamrtmtory component of the pathologic process but the reversibility of the pulmonary fibrosis has not been documented, Isolated case studies have described a possible value of high doses steroids in promoting recovery from Neomycin lung toxicity.

A 29 year old woman treated for Hodgld~a's disease was admitted to. the ICU for dyspnea and h~cpoxemia 15 days after her fourth chemotherapeutic course including Neomycin. All cultures including bronoho-alveolar lavage fluid remained negative. As the suspected diagnosis was bleomycir~ toxicity, methylprednisotone lg/day for 3 days followed by tapered doses was administred but her pulmonary status continued to deteriorate so that she was considered for exlra-corporeal lung support ~2/FtO2 = 67 with a PEEP at 10 cm H20, peak pressure 40 can H20 and I.E. at 1.1). As the evolution of bleomycine induced fibrosis is unknown if the toxic effect of high pressure and O2 are removed and as the prognosis of her Hodgkin's disease was good,, she was placed on low flow vent-venous extracorporeal support (ECCO2R). After 35 days of support, no improvement was noted. A open lung biopsy showed massive interstitial fibrosis and disappearance of the nermal alveolar structure; As she was not candidate for lung transplantation, it was decided not to change the oxygenators when they would fail and the patient died on day 45 of support from progressive hypoxemia. This case illustrates the evolution of Neomycin-induced fibrosis if no response to steroids is observed : even if any possible toxicity of the ventilation is removed,the evolution is towards irreversible fibrosis. We conclude that extracorporeal lung support is probably contra-indicated in patients with suspected bleomycin toxicity.

body_text.text: To assess the usefulness that the measurement of the respiratory mechanics (RM) and the portable chest x-ray film have to know the causes of ventilatory failure (VF). DESIGN and SETTING: Prospective study with follow up to ICU discharge. A multidisciplinary adult ICU in a 650 beds hospital. PATIENTS: 100 patients (average age 58) were studied: 15 postsargical without cardio-pulmonary pathology who were selected for the control group, and 85 consecutive patients with VF from different causes. METHODS: Patients were intubated, adecuatcly sedated and paralyzed, and mechanically ventilated using a Serve 900C Siemens ventilator. Airway pressure (Paw) and Flow (V) were measured with pressure transducers incorporated into ventilator. All the RM measures and x-ray film were made immediately after the endotracheal intubation, except in the control group (3.5 + 1.5 hours after they were intubated). In each patient we obtained the static inflation compliance of the total respiratory system (Cst, rs), the total inspiratory resistence (Pit) and the "intrinsic PEEP" (ante-PEEP); also recorded the appearance of Paw and V forms. RESULTS: We found four patterns ofRM (A: Cst,rs ~ ; B: Ritlland auto-PEEP; C: Cst, rs ~ and Pit I and auto-PEEP; and D: RM normal, like control group). Using these patterns whithout knowing others clinic data from the patients, and after comparing with the final diagnostic, we had a mistake physiopathologic diagnosis in 5 (6%) eases (3 with pulmonary edema, 1 with pneumonia and septic shock and other with pneumonia and neuromuscular disease), in whom the x-ray let us to make the exact diagnostic. On the other hand, when we use only the x-ray film, in 18 (21%) cases we couldn't make a right diagnosis (8 patients with COPE), 1 with pneumonia and septic shock and 9 with defective technique in x-ray film); the RM facilited us the correct diagnosis in these patients. CONCLUSIONS: 1) The RM constitutes an excellent test in patients with VF and let us to know the main physiopathologic alteration with better reliablely than portable chest x-ray film. 2) Both RM and chest x-ray film are necessary to know the causes of VF.

The ability to breathe spontaneously depends on the respiratory drive and the load and capacity of the respiratory muscles. Intermittent mechanical ventilation (MV) has been shown to improve ventilatory function in hypercapnic patients. Thus, we studied changes in drive, load and capacity of the respiratory muscles during this therapy. Method: In 19 hypercapnic patients (9 COPD, 6 scoliosis, 4 neuromuscular), who were successfully treated by intermittent MV (2 via tracheostomy, 17 nasal mask) respiratory drive was assessed by CO 2rebreathing and by the CO 2-recruitment threshold Pco 2RT, defined as the lowest Pco 2, at which spontaneous respiratory activity could be detected in a mechanically hyperventilated patient. The demand on the respiratory muscles was determined by the mouth occlusion pressure P0.1 during spontaneous breathing in percent of its maximum (P 0.1 ma)} Results: The response in minute volume VE (0.36) and in occlusion pressure P0.1(0.2) to CO 2was markedly reduced compared to normal subjects (1.42 and 0.66). The P0.1 in percent of its maximum, however, representing the relative drive, was increased by at least 60% at any given Pco 2. The Pco 2RT decreased from 62+__10 to 44±8mmHg during intermittent IPPV, while spontaneous Pco 2 decreased from 60~+9 to 41 +__6. The demand on the respiratory muscles was critically increased to 0.26, but decreased during therapy due to an increase in ventilatory capacity (p < 0.001 ).

We conclude, that respiratory drive is increased in chronic hypercapnia and that a further increase in drive would fatigue the respiratory muscles. The Pco2RT is increased, resulting in hypoventilation and by this in a decrease in the load on the respiratory muscles. Ventilatory capacity does increase due to intermittent I PPV. Spontaneous Pco2and Pco 2RT can be resetted to normal. Intermittent passive ventilation, normalizing the arterial Pco 2, should therefore be the ventilatory mode of choise in patients with thoracic disorders requiring ventilatory support.

We report on 54 COPD patients with chronic stable hypercapnia, treated prospectively with intermittent IPPV over 5 years. Method: 54 patients 63!9 years, 44 male, 10 female, suffering from advanced COPD, Fevl = 0.8+0.31, RV/TLC = 75+10 % were treated with nasal intermittent tPPV after several weeks of inhospital medical treatment, including theophylline, I~-sympathomimetics and corticosteroids, Infections and cardiac failure had been resolved before nasal IPPV was started. An individual mask was used to access the airways. Controlled mechanical ventilation was performed during the night and several hours during the day (Pco 2during ventilation 35!6 mmHg). Oxygen consumption (VO2) has been claimed to be a predictor of survival in critically ill patients. To evaluate VO2 as as a predictor, metabolic gas exchange (Deltatrac, Datex) was continously measured in a total of 150 days in 61 consecutive mechanically ventilated ICU patients in whom the APACHE-II score also was calculated for each day. Of the indices of metabolic gas exchange VO2 was the most powerful predictor of survival ( 314_+ 54 in survivors vs 266_+ 79 ml/min in non-survivors,p<0.0001), but also carbon dioxide production (VCO2) and energy expenditure were elevated in survivors (p<0.001). In a multiple logistic analysis, VO2 was found to be a more powerful predictor of survival than the APACHE-II score ( p<0.0001 and p<0.0005 respectively ), but these variables were independent and additative predictors of survival. Conclutions: Indices of metabolic gas exchange, especially VO2, were found to be predictors of survival in mechanically ventilated ICU patients.As the ability of VO2 to predict outcome was superior, and additative, to the APACHE-II score measurements of VO2 would provide an additional tool to evaluate the prognosis of critically ill patients.

ARDS progressed in 3 patients with refractory hematologic disease and they died. One patient who recovered from severe bone marrow aplasia was weaned from vantilatory support after 21 days, A patient with acute upper airway obstruction was extubated after 5 days when the local finding subsided. No major lung hemorrhagic complication developed in the both survivors and nonsurvivors.

We conclude that ARD$ complicating pneumonia is a leading cause of acute espiratory failure in patients with hematologic malignancies. Its mortality remains high in patients with persistence / progression of their hematologic disease. Patients who are suncesfully treated for their underlying disease have better prognosis, Despite severe hrombocytopenia no majqr lung parenchymal hemorrhagic complications occured in patients treated by mechanical ventilation. The mechanical effects of HME's in patients under mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory failure (ARF) have not been thoroughly investigated. Methods.The problem was studied on 10 patients, assisted by pressure support (PS) ventilation for ARF. The following 3 conditions were randomly tested on each patient: the control condition, without HME, the use of a low volume HME (LV), the use of a high volume HME (HV). Continuous monitoring of P0.1 and close loop regulation of the PS level based on this parameter, were applied in order to maintain a constant patient inspiratory activity during the whole study. After 20 rain in each condition, measurements of ventilatory pattern, gas exchange and, in 5 patients, inspiratory mechanical work, were performed. Results, See 10.8 -+ 1.6 12_+ 1.6 0.01 Alveolar volume (Vt minus Vd), respiratory rate, minute alveolar ventilation (V'a), pit and PaCO2 did not show significant changes. The use of the HME's, and especially Of HV, significantly increased the dead space ventiIation (V'd). The constancy of V'a, pH, and PaCO2 despite the higher V'd depended from a compensatory increase of minute ventilation (V'e), and thus of total inspiratory work (Witot). The higher load due to the HME's was entirely compensated by the ventilator, which developed higher PS levels, being the servocontrol effective to maintain the constancy of P0A and hence of patient inspiratory work (Wipat). Conclusion. HME's have unfavourable mechanical effects due to the increase of Vd. Inhaled NO can improve arterial oxygenation in acute lung injury. We retrospectively evaluated the frequency and the magnitude of this effect in 20 consecutive mechanically ventilated ARDS patients, by analysing the changes of PaO2 observed during short tests of NO inhalation. The tests were performed in order to assess the interest for a terapeutical use of inhaled NO in each individual patient, Methods. 18 patients were assisted by controlled ventilation, and 2 by pressure support ventilation. The mean PEEP level was 8_+3.6 cmH20, and the mean FiO2 was 0.6_+0,2, The Murray lung injury score (LIS) was 2.8_-20.59. The concentration of inhaled NO averaged 14_+ 6 ppm. Two blood gas analysis were performed, one immediately before and one during NO inhalation, 15 min after the start. A pair of PaO2 data was therefore obtained for each patient, which were compared by the t-test. Patients were arbitrarily classified as responders when an increase of PaO2 from baseline was observed _>10%. Results. The baseline PaO2 averaged 75_+22 mmHg, and significantly increased to 94-+35 mmHg during NO inhalation (P=.0007). Considering the individual response to the NO (see picture), 12 responders could be identified, showing a mean increase of PaO2 from baseline by 41-+26%, while 8 patients were non-responders (mean change +t_+4%). No clinically significant decrease of PaO2 was observed during NO inhalation. The response to the NO did not con-elate with the LIS (r=0.039). Conelusions, Inhaled NO at the dose of 14+_6 ppm increased on the average the PaO2 in a group of ARDS patients, the individual response being however variable. A deterioration of oxygenation was never observed. Even if the criteria for predicting the response to NO still remain to be defined, a short test can easily identify the responders and the magnitude of the response. Recent studies have shown that acute lung injury (ALl) is characterized not only by altered lung compliance but also by increased lung resistance. We studied 16 mechanically ventilated patients with ALl (8 moderate and 8 severe (ARDS)) and 8 normals anesthetized paralyzed subjects (control) at the same tidal volume (0.5 L) and inspiratory flow (0.5 L/s). Lung compliance (Cpl,I), total lung resistance (Rmax,I), airway resistance (Rmin,I), additional lung resistance (DR,I) were measured using the esophageal ballon technique during costant flow inflation without positive end-expiratory pressure applied. Functional residual capacity (FRC) was measured by helium dilution technique. Specific (s) lung compliance (L/cmH20/L) and resistance (cmH20/L/s.L) were obtained standardizing lung compliance and resistance to FRC (L). Results (mean + SD) are shown in tn conclusion in ALl patients: 1)lung compliance is reduced and lung resistances (total, airway and additional) are increased; 2) specific lung compliance is normal. The main cause of the reduction in lung compliance and increase in lung resistance in ALl patients could be attributed to reduced functional residual capacity.

However, there is some controversy about the definition of entry cdteda and the comparison of patients treated with or without ELA, This I~aper evaluates the entry criteda of ECMO in patients with severe ARDS either treated with ELA or with conventional advanced treatment and presents a concept for a standardised protocol Using a computerised expert system, with fuzzy logics we retrospectively analysed 78 patients with severe ARDS treated either with (n=30) or without (n=48) ELA at the UKRV/Berlin. By comparing ELA and non-ELA patients the most significantly different parameters were: PaO2/FiO2<70 in ELA 73% (vs 2,6% in non-El_A), EVLW was 90% (vs 66% in non-ELA), Q$/QT >30 94% (vs 60% in non-ELA) and PaO2<60 in 48% in ELA (vs 18% in non-ELA). Pernerstorfer, D. Koc, AF Hammerle Hypothermia might play an important role in the achievement of optimal values in oxygen delivery as well as consumption. However, the concept of moderate hypothermia induced by continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVHF) has gained only little attention for the therapy of septic ARDS (1,2). The goal of our investigation was therefore to test the hypothesis that moderate hypothermia enables the achievement of optimal va}ues in oxygen kinetics in patients suffering from septic ARDS. Methods: Over a 24 month period, 27 patients with ARDS and sepsis were recruited to the study, in all patients CVVHF was performed after fulfilment of the following criteda: a) Murray score >2~5, b) hyperthermia of > 38°C, c) cardiovascular instability requiring inotropic support and fluid resuscitation. Evaluation of oxygen delivery (DO2) and oxygen consumption (VO2) was performed every 4 hours. Core temperature (Temp) measured by the pulmonary artery thermistor was targeted at 34,5 to 35,9°C by CVVHF therapy. Optimal resuscitation and oxygen kinetics ,,,/as defined according Shoemaker et al (3). Linear regression analysis was used to compare the relationship between temperature and oxygen kinetics. Results: Septic shock occured in 10 of 14 nonsurvivors and in 2 of 13 survivors. During moderate hypothermia, the incidence of optimal DO2 was 42 + 21% in nonsurvivors and 25 + 19% in survivors of ARDS (p<0.05). Optimal VO2 was found in 13 + 9% of nonsurvivors compared to 9 + 6% of survivors. The relationship between DO2 and Temp was in the range from 0.3% to 52% in nonsurvivors and from 0.1% to 45% in survivors. Overall mortality of our study patients was 52%. We conclude, that the concept of moderate hypothermia in septic ARDS does not result in either improved DO2 / VO2 relationship or improved survival rates. Moreover, supranormal values for oxygen delivery was attained even more frequent in patients ultimately succumbing ARDS. However, previous studies found both, responders and non-responders to these strategy (1,2). The goal of our study was to investigate the immediate response of oxygen kinetics (i.e. oxygen consumption and delivery) during this procedure. Methods: We investigated 12 patients (age 19-72; 3 males) after severe trauma (ISS 35-75) requiring mechanical ventilation for more than one week. Further entry criteria were: PaO 2 <100 with pressure limited IRV (max. 35mmHg, I:E=2:1) at Fie 2 > 0,5 and PEEP > 8mmHg and radiologic signs of ARDS for > 24 hours following admission to ICU. Immediately before and 30 minutes after each position change respiratory, haemodynamic and oxygenation data were recorded. All patients were monitored by pulmonary artery catheter providing cardiac output by thermodilufion and measurements of arterial (CaO2) and mixed venous (CvO2) oxygen content. Oxygen consumption and delivery were calculated according to Fick's principle. Results: Changing body position from supine to prone resulted in a significant increase in oxygen consumption in 3 out of 12 patients, in one patient a significant decrease in VO 2 eccured. Oxygen delivery increased significantly in 4 out of 12 patients.
In 8 patients neither a significant change in VO 2 nor in DO 2 was observed.

Conclusion: These preliminary results show that whole body's oxygen kinetics are not uniformely influenced by the improvement in arterial oxygenation and decrease of pulmonary shunt fraction. Whether increases in VO 2 or DO 2 in some individual patients reflect an increase in metabolic rate or tissue oxygen demand will be the subject of further investigations. [Results] Twenty-eight patients met our criteria.
Twenty-two patients were intubated for more than 48 hours (3-48 days, mean 11 days). Six patients were not intubated or were intubated for less than 24 hours.

[Discussion] Various complications were found in many patients, many of these patients were immuno-compromized, were receiving steroid or anticoagulant therapy, complicated by DIC and were ventilator dependent.

Although preventing these complications seems to be difficult, it is important in managing ICU patients. In our pig peritonitis model of the adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) we invesLigated the effect of dopexamine hydrochloride on the PaO2/FiO2 ratio, pulmonary artery pressure, pulmonary vascular resistance and pulmonary ultrastructure.

12 pigs (25-30 kg) were randomised into 2 groups, dopexamine (D) and placebo (P). Anaesthesia was induced and catheters inserted to measure arterial (MABP), pulmonary artery (MPAP) blood pressures and cardiac output (CO). A laparotomy was performed and 35 ml of cecal content removed.

Dopexamine or placebo was started with an intravenous infusion of colloid to increase cardiac output by at least 25%. Peritonitis ('PI) was induced with the cecal content and measurements taken. The animals were culled after 8 hours and lung tissue taken for electron microscopy. In the P group PaO2/FiO2 ratio did not change with volume expansion but fell significantly over 8 hours. In the D group there was a fall with dopexamine administration, but there were no changes during the infection period. After 8 hours the ratio was significantly lower in the P group than the D group. PVR in the P group rose significantly after infection and was significantly higher than the D group. PVR in the D group did not change significantly over the 8 hours of the study.

In the P group electron ndcrographs of the pulmonary ultrastructure showed the development of leukostasis, capillary occlusion and swollen endothelinm. In the D group there was little leukostasis, capillary occlusion or endothelial swelling. Dopexamine appears to have reduced the ARDS like changes normaly associated with this animal model.

We recently studied the effects of aerosolized prostaglandin (PG) 12 in 3 patients with acute severe ARDS. Doses between 17 to 50 ng/kg-min, nebulized into the afferent limb of the ventilator circuit, decreased the mean pulmonary artery pressure (PAP; mean ~-SEM) from 40.3 ± 13.5 to 32.0 ± 3.8 mmHg, whereas the mean systemic arterial pressure (SAP) declined only marginally. Concomitantly, the ratio of arterial oxygen to the fraction of inspired oxygen (paO2/FiO2) increased from 119.5 ± 19.3 to 173 ± 17.7 mmHg, largely due to a redistribution of blood flow from shunt areas to regions with normal ventilationperfusion ratios (multiple inert gas elimination technique). All effects were reversible upon withdrawal of the drug. We now extended this approach to patients mechanically ventilated due to severe community-acquired pneumonia. Group A included patients without preexisting tung disease (n = 6), and group B those with underlying chronic fibrotic interstitial lung disease (n = 6). In group A, low doses of aerosolized PGI 2 (mean 6.6 ± 3.0 ng/kg.min) sufficed to decrease the mean pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) from 35.0 ± 1.5 to 31.0 ± 1.6 mmHg, to improve PO2/FiO 2 from 100 ± 18 to 134 ± 18 mmHg, and to decrease intrapulmonary shunt (36.9 ± 4.7 to 27.5 ± 4.5 %). Systemic arterial pressure (SAP) and cardiac output remained unchanged. In group B, aerosolized PGI 2 was ineffective up to 10 ng/kg'min. At a mean dosage of 33.6 ± 12ng/kg-min, aerosolized PGI 2 reduced PAP (38.0 ~: 2.4 to 30.8 ± 2.1 mmHg), but also decreased SAP (80.3 ± 3.6 to 71.3 ± 4.7 mmHg) and paO2/FiO 2 values (73.8 ± 6.6 to 65.5 ± 6.8 mmHg) and increased intrapulmonary shunt (44.7 ± 3.0 to 49.4 ± 5.0 %). A~er withdrawal of the PGI 2 aerosol, all gas exchange and hemodynamic variables returned to preaerosol baseline values within 60 min. We conclude that low doses of; aerosolized PGI 2 may reduce pulmonary hypertension and improve matching of ventilation and perfusion in the absence of significant systemic effects in patients with severe ARDS and pneumonia However, when interstitial fibrosis is present as underlying disease, manifold higher PGI 2 doses are required for induction of pulmonary vasoditation, then accompanied by systemic vasorelaxation and increased intrapulmonary shunt flow. Introduction: In recent years the percutanous dilatational tracheostomy has become a method of increasing attractivity. We report about one of the largest prospective series worldwide.

From june 1992 to december 1993 a percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy was performed prospectively on 275 ICU patients (159m, 116f; average age 54 [11-92] years) after a mean time of endotracheal intubation of 6 days. Using the dilatational technique described by Ciaglia, the tracheostomy was always controlled by intraoperative tracheoscopy. All procedures were performed in the ICU. 139 patients had risk factors (49 short fatty neck, 32 goiter, 35 thrombocytopenia <50.000 plt/mm 3, 23 immunosuppression).

The percutaneous technique could always be done sufficiently with installation of a 8 or 9 mm cannula. The mean time of the procedure was 8 (1,5-30) rain. One patient died perioperatively because of acute cardiac failure not due to the percutaneous tracheostorey, another patient died after false exchange of the tracheal cannula into the anterior mediastinum 5 days after primary dilatational procedure. Other severe complications occured in 6 patients (4 bleedings, 1 cuff-defect, 1 accidental decannulation), The over-all complication rate was 9,1% concerning any problem during more than 6500 days of treatment. None of 101 decannulated patients had signs of a tracheal stenosis clinically or radiologically.
The percutaneous dilatational lracheostomy is quick and save. It should become the standard procedure on critically ill patients in the ICU for prolonged venftlation or airway protection.

A 6 week old male infant was admitted unconsciously to the ICU after primary CPR at home. There were no external signs of head injury. On admission the child's ventilation was insufficient. It had tonic and clonic convulsions. The ophthalmological examination revealed bilateral retinal hemorrhage. Thus, a shaking baby syndrom was suspected.

The cranial ultrasound was normal, but measurement of cerebral blood flow velocity by Doppler sonography showed a negative enddiastolic flow in the internal carotid artery (1CA) and middle cerebral artery (ACM). A subsequent CCT examination showed diffuse brian swelling, and a frontally located subdural hematoma und subarachnoidal hemorrhage. Thereafter the subdural hematoma was evacuated and ICP monitoring was installed.

Initially, ICP was about 30 mmHg. Intravenous administration of mannitol led to an immediate decrease in ICP, with a concomitant decrease of the resistance index (RI) in ACM and ICA for a period of 2 to 3 hours. Mannitol was the only effective drug to control ICP where hyperventilation was uneffective. A significant correlation was found between ICP and RI change. ICP was abnormally elevated for four days and normatised thereafter. 8 weeks later the child was discharged with severe neurological deficits.

The negative enddiastolic flow pattern measured by Doppler sonography indicated comprimised cerebral blood flow, and is proposed as noninvasive method for providing informations on cerebral perfusion even in emergency condition.

In patients with supratentorial mass lesions, pupillary enlargement and especially bilateral mydriasis is aonsidered the surest sign of uncal herniation. Jugular bulb oximetry provides bedside continuous information on cerebral blood flow adequacy. In this paper we report on the clinical importance of jugular bulb oxygen saturation (sin2) monitoring in patients developping bilateral mydriasis. Twenty severely head injured pts (GCS<8, supratentorial lesions) develnpping bilateral mydriasis during jugular bulb oximetry monitoring will be discussed. Alt 20 pts developped intraeranial hypertension despite maximal therapy (CSF drainage/hyperventilation/mannitol and barbiturates). In 12 pts we noted a sudden and excessive decrease in jugular oxygen saturation (mean sin2 of 23%). In 4 pts this decrease was noted shortly (5-I0 rain) before pupillary enlargement, in 8 pts after (10-60 rain) pupillary enlargement. In all 12 pts, this sharp decrease in sin2 was followed (withira 5 mira) by an almost immediate increase in SjO2 to extremely high levels (all more than 90%). In 6 of the 8 other pts a slow increase (over 15-60 min) in sin2 was observed to levels of more than 90% . In all these 18 pts with SjO2 of more than 90%, brain death was ultimaltely (12 hours later) confirmed by cerebral angiography, tn 2 pts no change in sin2 occurred and angiography revealed adequate cerebral circulation. In both pts pupillary light reflexes returned to normal again (after 24h and after 3 days respectively). Both survived and had moreover a good neurologic recovery. These misleading pupillary findings may have been the result of treatment sideeffects. Ira one pt administration of catecholamines (a&enaline) may have been the cause. In the other pt, barbiturates in combination with catecholamines may be blamed. Both dangerously misleading situations were indicated by the absence of any change in NO2.

In conclusion, these data call for extreme vigilance as to the interpretation and the possible therapeutic eensequences of bilateral fixed mydriasis in severely head injured patients. Especially the side-effects of intensive treatment (cateaholaminas, barbiturates, narcotics, paralyzing agents) can confound the interpretation of pupillary light reflexes and cause misleading and dangerous situations. Jugular bulb oximetry seems to be a readily available bedside help for thesemisleading situations.
