The consequences of traumatic brain injury commonly observed are the increase of intracranial pressure and the suppression of the immune system. Recently, brain cells have been studied for their participation in the inflammatory response and in particular for the production of cytokines. For this purpose we monitored the production of IL-6, 3NF~ and IL-1 in ventricular CSF and serum of 12 patients with isolated brain injury and attempted to correlate cytokine levels to the outcome, using the Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS).
Patients with an initial Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) ~ and CT abnormalities received an intraventricular ICPM (intraeranial pressure monitoring) device.

Cerebrospinal fluid was drained when intracranial pressure exceeded 15 mm Hg and was analyzed in 12 patients for the presence of IL-6, TNFct and FL-1 by ELISA. Peripheral blood serum was assayed in parallel. Lumbar CSFs from 5 patients without neurological pathologies were analyzed as controls.

Our analysis showed that IL-6 was present in the CSF of all brain injured patients. IL-6 concentrations were significant higher in.CSF compared to serum and in some samples were found up to t00-fold higher. IL-6 could not be correlated to the GCS. However, patients with severe brain injury and moderate GOS showed high IL-6 levels, whereas patients with a good GOS had significant lower concentrations of 1L-6. TNFc~ and ~-1 could not be detected neither in CSF nor in serum of all patients. Control CSFs and sera were also negative for all mediators.

These results show that a dramatic activation of the immune system occurs after traumatic brain injury in humans, in particular within the CNS, suggesting that glial cells may play an important role in the pathophysiology of brain injury. Since relevant differences have been observed at the site of injury compared to the periphery and since the amounts of 1L-6 found in the CSF correlated to the outcome (GOS), this eytokine may be used as a parameter to judge the severity of brain damage. Hassler Introduction: The mortality rate for intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) ranges between 60 and 1OO %. Major factors for this poor prognosis are increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and compression of periventricular brain structures by the solid intraventricutar blood clot. Patients, methods: In 25 patients with moderate to severe WH 2 to 5 mg of rt-PA were injected into the ventricular system via an external ventricular drainage. F. Salord, C. Fischer, JP. ClaudeI, C. Jourdan, F. Maugui~re.

Adult patients remaining in coma 24 hours after a cardiac arrest usually have a poor prognosis. However, clinical examination is often not sufficient to precise the individual prognosis in the first days. Ethical, medical and economical considerations may be involved in the decision to limit, withdraw or withhold therapeutics. During the last 5 years, 50 pts (age>15) were studied. They had a normal neurological status before the accident. All of them remained comatous (Glasgow coma score<6) 24 hours after a cardiac arrest and were in a steady state (haemedynamics, ventilation, metabolic status, central temperature). They were mechanically ventilated and did not receive any sedative drug. In order to have an idea of the prognosis, EEG, brainstem auditory evoked potentials (BAEP), middle latency AEP (MLAEP), and somesthesic EP (SEP) were performed at the bedside in the first 4 days. Patients were paralyzed during the procedure (2-4 hours). Twenty-one pts (42 p.cent) died within the fisrt 2 weeks after stroke. They had abnormal BAEP in all cases, and in most of them had no cortical responses of the MLAEP and SEP. EEG activity was diseontinuated in all, and nearly isoetectric in 2 patients. Twenty pts (40 p.cent) remained in a persistant or chronic vegetative state. They all had normal BAEP, abnormal cortical responses of the MLAEP and SEP, and unreactive EEG. Nine pts (18 p.cent) awoke from coma. They all had severe sequaelae according to the Glasgow Outcome Scale. BAEP were normal. MLAEP and SEP cortical responses were present; latencies were delayed and peak/peak to peak amplitudes reduced. In this study, early electrophysiological data were interesting in the prediction of death or persistant coma. On the opposite, when patients awoke from deep coma, the quality of neurological evolution was not accurately prognosed. Electrophysiotocal data reflect the severity of anoxic and ischemic cerebral suffering: cortical responses are always abnormal or lacking; when subcortical and brainstem responses are abnormal, severe mesencephalum lesions and bad prognosis are expected. Different procedures (cognitive potentials, cerebral blood flow evaluation or PET scan) may be proposed to improve the prediction.

body_text.text: The purpose of the presented study was to identify easily obtainable prognostic factors for short term outcome of emergency victims treated by physician manned helicopter emergency medical systems (HEMS).

Using a Cox proportional hazards model, independent predictors for 30 day survival after helicopter rescue were assessed. Data were retrospectively obtained from the "Christophorus 1" operation protocols and from medical records of the further treating hospitals.

From 1/1/1989 to 12/31/1991 2652 missions were flown by the "Christophorus 1" HEMS based at Innsbruck airport. Treatment included the whole spectrum of medical emergencies but was dominated by sport accidents, malrdy ski injuries. Mean flight time to the scene was 14,2 rain, the mean duration of treatment at the scene was 12,8 rain. 66,5% of patients were male, 33,5% were female, the mean age was 35,3 years. The mean NACA (National Advisory Commitee of Aeronautics) score was 3,5. 10,2 % of all patients were intabated at the scene in primary tasks. Complete follow-up data gould be obtained from 1686 patients (= 63,3%). Cumulative 30 day survival was 88% for primary missions and 82% for interhospital flights, 100 % for NACA scores 0 to 3, 97% for NACA 4, 87%, for NACA 5 and 15% for NACA 6. The Cox proportional hazards model revealed that severity of the emergency according to the NACA score (p = 0,000), state of conciousness (p = 0,000), duration of treptmem at the scene (p= 0,004) and patient age (p = 0,045) were each significant predictors of short term survival after helicopter transport.

Therefore, the aim of this clinical study was to elucidate the effects of unilateral lung.tissue injury on activation of various mediators during thoracic surgery, Methods: 29 patients were examined for the perioperative release of several prostanoids: prostacyclin (PG12) and thromboxane A 2 ((TXAa) representing pulmonary endothelial reactions; prostaglandin E~ (PGE~ and neopterin standing for macrophage activation; prostaglandin Fz~, (PGF~) and prostaglandin M (PGM) were used to determine lung metabolic activity, and PMN elastase as indicator of the activation of PMN granuloeytes. The patients were subdivided into 2 groups: group I (n=10, control) consisted of patients undergoing thoracotomy but without lung damage, whereas group II patients (n=19) had an additional lung tissue resection due to benign processes. Results: Unilateral lung lesions, surgically induced, lead to an activation of the PMNs; elastase levels were reversibly increased (p<0.01 group I vs: II). The thoracic trauma resulted in a release of PGI2 and TXA~ in both groups during operation. Lung injury, however, intensified those reactions (e.g. TXA 220-fold). The significant elevation of PGF~ concentration in group II was related to the lung tissue damage whereas the pulmonary' metabolic activity remained unimpaired, The surgical trauma per se induced an increase in PGEz but no marked release of neopterin. Conclusion: Though, there was only a small unilateral lung damage during selective surgery this tissue injury produced a release of various vasoactive as well as inflammatory and immunosuppressive mediators. This means that lung tissue laceration would cause a liberation and activation of mediators similar to that in polytraumatized patients, albeit to a less pronounced degree. Our results strongly emphasize the importance of any lung tissue injury regarding the outcome of those patients.

The evaluated group was small and very heterogenous. In some patients the increased percentage of B lymphocytes (CDI9+) was noticed (up to 40%), while the T lymphocytes population (CD3+) was diminished. There were no significant changes in percentage of helper (CD4) and cytotoxic/supressor (CD8) cells. The percentage of T helper/inducer (CD4+/CD45RA+) cells varied from 2 to 32%. Surprisingly in patients with severe cranial/cerebral trauma the population of double positive (CD4+/CD8+) T lymphocytes was strongly increased, reaching 44%. Such increase was transient and all values returned to normal after 2 to 3 weeks.

In the blood of patients with polytrauma significant changes of lymphocytes subpopulations were observed. The differences in lymphocyte count between the patients were probably due to different cytokine network activation.

In some cases an undifferentiated subpopulation of T cells was released to peripheral blood. SERVICIO The results of the first series of experiments showed, that the massive acute blood loss (24±4.2 ml/kg of body weight) in rabbits led to a response of the organism with a clear phase course. After a depression phase and a short transitive phase, the phase of shock developed, during which three periods are easily differentiated: an early period, stabilization, and a late period. The latter more or less suddenly turned into the phase of secondary hemorrhagic collapse; then the terminal phase developed. Their life duration was 1.2-+0.21 hours.

In the next series of experiments 10 animals had a reinfusion of blood in the early period of shock. Due to preservation of the function of the highest regulatory mechanisms, the organism could put into action the hemodynamic effect of blood transfusion, and all animals survived. The blood reinfusion in the late period of shock caused only an increase of life duration of the animals, and all of them died on average 4.2±0.88 hours after bleeding because of failure of regulatory mechanisms.

In the last series of experiments 5 rabbits after blood transfusion in the late period of shock had intravenously 0.1 mg/kg Dalarginesynthetic opiate peptide leu-encephaline. The stabilization of hemodynamic indices was achieved on the background of hypothermia, adynamia, muscle hypotonia and other evidence of torpidity. After 2-3 hours the state of these animals began gradually to improve, and all of them survived.

We can conclude, that additional activation of endogenic opiate system by Dalargine promoted the recovery of the functions of the highest mechanisms for regulation of cardio-and hemodynamics, which is the main condition for a favourable outcome of shock. Introduction. Rapid and proper administration of adequate volume of fluids is imperative to the successful resuscitation of the multi-injured patient. Difficulties regarding the establishment of the required intravenous lines for this purpose are well known to all those dealing with the polytrauma patient in the field. The administration of small volume of"hypertonic saline" -NaCI 7.5%-in order to restore intravascular volume has been recently introduced, based on experimental data, in certain countries of the western hemisphere(1). We undertook this study in order to examine the efficacy of this method in the resuscitation of polytrauma patients on the site of accident. Methods. Forty polytrauma patients were included in the study assigned randomly to two groups of 20, comparable regarding their demographic data and trauma severity score. Within t0 to 50 minutes after the emergency call the resuscitative team had established an intravenous line and administered either 250ml of NaCI 7,5% {group A}, or Lactated Ringer's (LR) {group B} at the greatest possible flow. In group A, LR was subsequently administered as a routine. Measurements of systemic arterial pressure (SAP), heart rate (HR), respiratory rate (RR), urine production, and clinical evaluation of the patients' condition, were obtained ini~ally and every lOminutes tilt the hospital admission. Results. A faster haemodynamic improvement was observed in group A, reported elapsing time less than 5minutes, compared to a greater than 20minutes time in group B. In both groups, successful resuscitation had been achieved, with the exception of 3 cases of uncontrollable bleeding, as it was judged by the hospital receiving team, No differences were mentioned, regarding patients' outcome, from both groups. Conclusions. Administration of 250ml NaCI 7.5% solution to multi-injured patients at the accute setting of the accident site provides a unique inexpensive volume replenishment within short time, does not require large-bore intravenous lines, and improves rapidly the haemodynamic profile. Final outcome does not seem to be affected by the kind of resuscitative fluids, at least under the conditions of the present study; the attainment of favorable haemodynamics remains the crucial factor.

Continuous enteral feeding (CEF) has been associated with decreased gastric acidity, thereby stimulating gastric colonization and increasing the risk for Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in critically ill patients. Intragastric acidity was measured with computerized continuous intragastrie pH monitoring (CIpH). Patients were randomized to receive IEF or CEF. Cultures for microbiological analysis were performed daily. Patients wore deemed colonized when colonization, present on admission, persisted, or when colonization was acquired during study. Arterial blood gas analysis are important for the management of critically ill patients. Arterial blood gas analyzers can also measure some of the biochemical parameters, particularly electrolytes, besides the blood gases. However, blood gas analysis are potentially affected by several factors. Our aim was to determine some of the conditions inwhich arterial blood sample analysis were affected. MATERIALS AND METHODS: 50 patients undergone major operations under general anaesthesia were accepted. At least 20-30 minutes after the commencement of the artificial ventilation,arterial blood samples were taken from the patients. 8 samples of 1 ml were taken from each patient. 4 of 8 samples were collected to plastic and remaining to glass syringes. Those 8 groups of samples were stored in different conditions and then analysed. RESULTS: pH of the samples were decreased significantly during storage for both types of syringes. Although PO 2 was decreased slightly during storage, too, there wasn't any significance for both types of syringe. SatO2, Hct, and Na + didn't change. However K + decreased within glass syringes and increased within plastic syringes during storage insignificantly. While Ca ++ levels of samples within plastic syringes didn't change, there was a significant decrease during storage for glass syringes. DISCUSSION: During the last decade, with the developing technology, arterial blood gas analysers could be used for other biochemical measurements, particularly for electrolytes. Those are also important determinations in diagnosis and therapy of the critically ill. In our results, some of the blood gas analysis parameters changed with delaying insignificantly. It seems that type of syringe didn't affect the results, except some electrolytes. Particularly, Ca ++ levels were significantly affected during storage within glass syringes. In conclusion, blood gas analysis should be made bedside. If time delay is supposed to be, results, particularly electrolytes, may not be within reliable limits.

Methods : In 8 critically [11 patients (mean Apache II score : 19 ± 2) requiring IABP for postoperative support (7) and endstage congestive heart failure 11 ) we evaluated cardiac output (CO) (thermodiluSon technic) and coeliac blood flow velocity (pulsed wave doppler 2,5 MHz) before weaning from IABP. body_text.text: Objectives: Evaluate a titrated, multi-drug regimen for the neurobehavioral control of severe delirium tremens, aided by cerebral function monitoring to titrate treatment regimens at the neuronal level Design: Prospective, clinical study. Setting: University .inflated, tertiary level medical center. Patients: A series of 20 consecutive patients with a diagnosis of acute delirium tremens. Methods: Patients with severe delirium tremens and the presence of tachycardia, hypertension, tachypnea, hyperpyrexia and autonomic dysfunction were began on a continuous infusion protocol of propofol for sedation, cloaldine for autonomic control, and esmolol for control of tachycaxdia, Level of sedation assessed by the Ramsay Scale and computer processed cerebral function was monitored continuously. Results: The initial mean Ramsay score of 1.0 dropped between 4.45 -5.4 during the first three hours of propofol infusion and was maintained throughout the period of sedation. Mean total dose of propofol administered was 16.4 g +/-11.55 g (range 24,84g-459.54 g) and the mean infusion rate throughout the study was 2.73 +/-1.13 mg/kg/hour. The duration of infusinu varied from 29 to 129 hours (mean 70.85 +/-26.37). Moderate decrease in MAP was observed from 117.1 to 106.8 mm Hg (ns). Mean heart rate slowed from 125.6 +/-15.3 to 108.9+/-15.4. Cerebral function depicted easily interpretable brain wave patterns consistency with sedation that rapidly reflected neuronal activity changes with drug regimen titration. Conclusions: We present the successful use of multi-layer treatment for delirium treatment using propofol in a closely tltrated continuous infusion, the alpha-2 agonist clonidine and the ultra-short acting, cardioselective beta-adrenergie antagonist esmolol, and continuous cerebral function monitoring to assess impact of treatment at the neuronal level

Acute renal failure due to several reasons including ischemia and application of nephrotoxic agents is a major problem in patients in an intensive care unit. To answer the question it" theophylline is also able to prevent the development of ARF in clinical models we performed our prospective study using radiographic contrast media (CM) induced renal failure as an experimental model of acute renal failure (ARF).

Vasospasms leading to myocardial ischemia or infarction are well known adverse effects of numerous natural and semi-synthetic ergot alkaloids but have only rarely been reported for dihydroergotamine (DHE). As an intranasal formulation DHE is now frequently used in the treatment of migraine but thus far no reports about coronary events have been published after intranasal application. We followed a patient with chronic coronary artery disease who experienced an acute myocardial infarction shortly after starting treatment with intranasal DHE for severe migraine. This 51-year old male caucasian had a 3-year history of coronary artery disease (50% stenoses of RCX and RIVA) presenting with 1-2 episodes of vasospastic angina at rest and on exertion occurring on average every 3 months. He was maintained on oral nifedipine (20mg bid) and aspirin (100rag qd). Because nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs provided only partial relief of his migraine attacks he was started on intranasal spray of DHE mesilate. Within 24 hours he administered 4 sprays of DHE (0.5mg each); after the second 2 sprays angina occurred and within the following 48 hours he experienced an episode of unstable angina pectoris with numerous attacks at rest. He subsequently was admitted with an acute posterior myocardial infarction for fibrinolytic therapy. Coronary arteriography performed before discharge from the hospital revealed a slight progression of atherosclerosis in RCX and RIVA and a successful catheter angioplssty of a 75% RCX stenosis was performed. After oral and parenteral administration DHE has been shown to cause Ionglasting vasoconstriction in numerous vascular beds and to promote coronary vasospasms. The close temporal association of intranasal DHE administration and myocardial infarction in this patient with previously stable coronary artery disease suggests a causal relationship. As advised by the manufacturer intranasal DHE should be avoided in patients with coronary heart disease. ~'evious studies haw indicated tL~t the true cost of antibiotic therapy involves considerably more than the agent; however, every aspect associated with treatment (i.e., administration supplies, laboratory monitoring, pharmacy preparation time, nursing administration time) was not evaluated in the ICUs. GW lenght outside the patient at the point of maximal insertion was measured by the operator (blinded of EKG tracing), with a sterile paper graduated strip; single or double tureen CVC for HD and/or TPN of different lenght were used, according to the vascular access (128 right subcl vein, 15 left subcl, vein, 13 intjug, vein) and patient height, No CA was found in 86 procedures out of 156 (55%); in the remaining 70 procedures, 161 CA episodes were recorded: atrial arrhythmias 48/161 (30%), ventricular arrhythmias 113/161 (70%). Statistically significant differences among frequencies of both CA and advanced ventricular arrhythmias [three or more consecutive VPB, VPB run of 3-5 eonsec, beats, non sustained VT with 5-30 consec, beats, sustained VT (Sprung CL, Am J Med 72:203, 1982): controls: 2/27; ARF ¢lroup: 19/54; ESRD .qroup: 13/41; HD group 5/34 ] were observed for both ARF and ESRD groups as compared to controls (p < .05, Chi-square or Fisher test as needed). All CA resolved spontaneously with the GW still in place, or soon after withdrawal; 9 CA were symptomatic (in one case TV episode, followed by 10 sec. asystolia due to I1[ ° atdoventricu[ar block). body_text.text: The incidence and prevalence of congestive heart failure (CHF) exponentially increase with age, creating peculiar problems of management in frail elderly patients (pts). To evaluate the feasibility of vend-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) in advanced age, we examined the results obtained in the whole series of 22 pts (mean age: 68+11 yearsyrs) treated with this tecnique in the last two years for chronic CHF (C-CHF) and for severe left ventricular dysfunction following acute myocardial infarction (AMI-CHF). Pts were divided into two agegroups (A: <70 yrs, n=ll, mean age: 60d:7 yrs and B: >70 yrs, n=11, mean age: 765:5 yrs). There were neither age-related differences in indications (C-CHF: A=B=63.6%, AMI-CHF: A=B=36.4%) nor in mean values of blood concentrations of creatinine, urea, sodium, potassium, and of pH, pC 2 and pCO 2, always demonstrating metabolic acidosis and renal failure. CVVH lasted slightly longer in younger (137+140 vs 104+88 hours, NS) and sicker pts (dead: 137+138 vs survived: 101+79 hours, NS). Mortality was not significantly age-associated (A: 50.0% vs B: 72.7%, NS). Weight reduction was lower in aged pts when the treatment was stopped (B: 2.6_+4.3 vs A: 11.0-+9.0 Kg, p<0.002), according to the need of a lower volume depletion in elderly pts to reach a significant clinical improvement. tn conclusion, CVVH, if properly regulated, revealed itself as a very useful tool in treating CHF also in advanced age, allowing greater survival rates tha~ traditional medical therapies in conditions generally associated with very high mortality rates. Fluvoxamine, a serotonin reuptake inhibitor, interacts with opiates by increasing the antinociceptive effect and decreasing development of tolerance [Luger T.J. et al. (1992) Anaesthesist 42:213]. Enkephalin and serotonin are believed to block calcium channels in the membranes of the nerve terminals, that obviously result in presynaptic inhibition. It was aim of our study to investigate if there is a direct influence of fluvoxamine on the /z-receptor binding of sufentanil. Methods: Animal care commitee approach. 1) In 10 rats, receiving a jugular vene catheter, antinociceptive effects were measured by hot plate and tail flick test. In group 1 sufentanil (50~g/kg/d), in group 2 a combination of sufentanil and fluvoxamine and in group 3 fluvoxamine (20mg/kg/d) were continuously injected. 2) In another set of experiments, 5 rats were sacrificed, brain was removed and membranes were prepared as described [Bhargava H.N. and Gulati A. (1990) European J. Pharmacol. 190:305-311] . This membrane preparation was taken for receptor binding studies with opiates in addition of fluvoxamine. It has been shown that serum magnesium (Mgs) value on admission in ICU patients could have a prognostic significance (Crit Care Med 1993, 21, 203) . Therefore, we prospectively investigated 284 consecutive patients (179 men) admitted to our medical ICU over a 6-month period. Mgs was determined by a colorimetric method. The main end-point was the patient outcome during the ICU stay. Mgs values on admission led to partition the patients into the following three groups : low (Mgs<0,75 areolA), normals (0,75_Mgs_l maul/l) and high (Mgs>l mmolfl). Patient survival was determined by actuarial method and survival rates were compared with Mantel-Haentzel test. Cox multiple regression model was used to control patient survival for the following covariates : Mgs, age, sex, SAPS, organ system failure (OSF) on the day of admission, previous health status, medical or postoperative context, mechanical ventilation. 'l'he earacleristics of the sample were as follows : age (mean_SD) 55__.19 years, SAPS 10_+6, OSF number 1_+1 (_2 in 33% of the patients), medical context for 244 patients (86%) and emergency postoperative for 40 (14%); 50% were mechanically ventilated within the first 24 hours. Mgs value amounted 0,79_+0,15 mmolA in the whole group. 101 patients (36%) were in the low Mgs group (Mgs 0,65_0,08 maul/l), 161 (57%) in the normal Mgs group (0,84-+0,06 maul/l) and 22 (8%) in the high Mgs group (1,11 _+0,1 maul/l). The overall ICU mortality rate reached 16% (44/284). Actuarial survival curves were different between the three Mgs groups (p<0,01); mean survival time was 17 days in the high Mgs group (mortality 48%) vs 30 days for the normal Mgs group (mortality I2%) vs 29 days for the low Mgs group (mortality 15%). Cox's model extracted SAPS and age. as the two covariales explaining independently ICU death. This prospective study showed: 1-a 43% prevalence of Mgs abnormalities among patients admitted to our ICU; 2-the absence of a significant link between Mgs on admission and outcome in ICU.

body_text.text: Only few reports exist in literature concerning acute intoxication with propafenone (class Ic antiarrhythmic agent) mostly due to suicidal ingestion. Case rej~ort: 1 hour after ingestion of 4g propafenone in suicidal intention a 48 year old woman was admitted to the emergency room. At home she was found unconscious (glasgow coma scale 7) but breathing spontaneously, hypotensive (80/30 mmttg) with a heart rate of 35 bpm. In hospital oral hrtubation was perfomaed and mechanical ventilatory support initiated. Because of persistent severe hypotension and bradycardia 0Amg epinephrine was achninistered. Subsequent ventricular flutter required several defibrillation and continuous rescueitation. After 20 minutes performing closed chest massage and additional drug therapy with dopamine and dobutamine sinusrhythm and a stable circulation could be established. For drug elimination a gastric lavage with instillation of activated charcoal and calcium gluconate was done. Furthermore the patient received an infusion of 0,5 g/h sodium-chloride and 250 mmol sodium bicarbonate to antagonize competetivly the sodium chmmel-blocker effect of propafenone and to balance the metabolic acidosis. Glucagon infusion was given to increase the cardiac inotropy. Retrospectively blood concentration of propafenone was elevated (2.98 mg/I; normal range: 0.25mg/1-2.0mg/1). 14 hours after admittance to the ICU the patient could be extubated without sigmes of neurologic deficits. The ECG-changes were completely normalised. Conclusion: Intoxication with the class Ic antiarrhytlm~ic drug propafenone is a rare but severe form of ingestion in suicidal intention. It may take a lifethreatening course because of the drug-induced dysrhythmias and the negative inotrop properties of the drug. Immediate rescuisitation, drug elimination and administration of sodium chloride is pivotal in treatment of propafenone intoxication. Infection is extremely common in the ICU and the EPIC Study has demonstrated a prevalence rate of 45 %. Nevertheless, it remains unclear whether the majority of critically ill patients die with or from infection. We have studied the incidence of infection (defined using the Centre for Disease Control [CDC] criteria) in our 13 bedded general adult ICU over a period of eight months and its relation to standardised mortality rate (SMR).

The present study was designed to investigate the influence of the storage temperature on the stability of pO2, pCO2 and pH in plastic syringes. Hundred blood samples were withdrawn on the intensive care unit from patients with indwelling arterial catheters. Blood samples were collected into 2 ml Lithium-heparin containing plastic syringes (Monovette R ffir Blutgas-Bestimmung, Sarstedt, D-Nfimbrecht) and stored at room temperature or in ice-water. Blood gas analysis was done with a IL 1306 pI-I/Blood Gas Analyzer (Instrumentation Laboratory, D-Kirchheim-Heimstetten) after 0, 20, 40, 60, 90 and 120 minutes. Results are given as means+SEM, comparisons were performed by means of the two-sample t test.

The average initial pOz values were 94.0 mmHg (59-137) and 92.2 mmHg (58-135). pO2 levels increased markedly at both storage conditions, however this increase was about twofold higher (p<0.001) in blood samples stored in ice-water 0.2+0.8, 19.4_+1.1 and 31.5+1.5 ntmHg after 20, 40 and 60 min) than in samples stored at room temperature (4.7_+0.6, 9.1 _+ 1.0, 12.9_+ 1.2 mmHg after 20, 40 and 60 min). pCO2 and pH did not change significantly in blood samples stored in ice-water whereas a slight increase of pCO2 (maximum 2.7_+0.2 mmHg) and a slight decrease of pH (maximum -0.04_+0.002) was observed. However, the changes of pCOz and pH were very small as compared to the marked pO2 increase in blood samples stored in ice-water. Thus the present data provide support that preanalytic cooling of arterial blood samples, collected in the plastic syringes used in the present study or in similar plastic syringes, might induce more pronounced aIterations of PO2 levels than storage at room temperature. Introduction: Urodilatin, a newly identified analogue of human ANP, has potent diuretic and natriuretic effects even in low doses in healthy subjects. Acute renal failure after major abdominal surgery is a severe complication with a high mortality in intensive care units (ICU). The aim of the study was to explore whether or not urodilatin improves postoperative acute renal failure and reduces the need of hemodialysis. Methods: This randomized study was approved by the local ethics committee, which requested to limit the number of patients to 12 subjects under double-blind placebo-controlled conditions. Twelve consecutive nonoliguric patients in the ICU after major abdominal surgery with no history of impaired renal function were admitted to the study, when serum creatinine had reached acutely 2.5 mg/dl or endogenous creatinine clearance was reduced to 15 ml/min despite low-dose dopamine (2,5/zg/kg BW/min) and furosemide (1000rag/24 h) therapy. All patients were ventilated artificially and monitored extensively regarding hemodynamic and biochemical parameters. Urodilatin (n=6) or vehicle (n=6) was infused continuously in a dose of 20 ng/kg/min for at least 4 in maximum 6 days additionally to the conventional diuretics therapy. Results: Serum creatinine was similar at the day before the onset of urodilatin infusion in both groups (2,93_+0.48 mg/dl, 2.80+0.24 mg/dl). During application of urodilatin/vehicle peak serum creatinine was reduced from 5.78+1.58 mg/dl in the vehicle-to 4.65_+0.57 mg/dl in the urodilatiu-treated groups (P=0.t48). Hemodynamic parameters were not altered due to urodilatin/vehicle treatment. The total number of hemodialysis because of oligoanuria and/or dramatic rise of serum urea, creatinine, and K +, was the same in both groups (14/15) during the trial (6 days).

In patients with established acute renal failure urodilatin was capable of reducing peak serum creatinine compared to vehicle treatment. The data suggest that urodilatin might have more beneficial effects in improving acutely impaired renal function with an earlier or prophylactic onset of therapy and a higher dose of urodilatin.

body_text.text: In South Moravian region housing about 1.9 million inhabitants, approximately one thousand patients are treated with lithium. Over the 25 years of lithium application, four lethal intoxications were reported in the region, three of them being suicides,

All the three female patients took a high dose of sustained-release lithium product (Contemnol, Slovakofarma). In two cases, the doses were approximately known (50 and 70 g, resp.); in one case, the dose has not been established. Maximum lffhium levels detected in individual patients were 8.4, 10.0 and 3.2 retool/I, resp. In two cases, the intoxicmions were combined with additional psychotherapeutical drugs which was manifested by initial loss of consciousness. After a temporary improving of consciousness, signs of neurotoxicity emerged in all the three patients on day 3, followed by a refractory shock. Two of the patients died on the 5th day and one of the patients died on the 12th day after taking the lethal dose of lithium. In one of the patients, autopsy revealed undissolved lithium tablets in the stomach and remainders of the tablets in the intestines in spite of gastric lavage which had been carried out. In another patient, high levels of lithium (34 and 11.3 mmol/I, resp.) were found in the gastric lavage returns on the 1st and 2nd days.

Severe lithium intoxications undergo several phases. A loss of consciousness occurs in a comparatively late phase. Until then, the severity of intoxication may be underes~ timated. Serum lithium level is the most important criterion in the earlier phases. Coma is preceded by confusion state and agitation. In sustained-release lithium products, the removal of tablets from the gastrointestinal tract represents a particularly sedous problem.

Introduction: Patients with pancreatitis in a ICU ordinate from 2 groups: most of them are admitted because of the pancreatitie, and the most frequent causative factors are cholelithiasis or ethanol. A smaller group of up to 15% is initially admitted because of other diseases and develops "secondary" pancreatitis as complication. Among the reasons are disorders of coagulation and metabolism, medications, intoxications, infections, vasculitis and medical interventions as abdominal operations and ERCP. This paper presents three case reports in order to show the specific problems in diagnosis and treatment of "secondary" pancreatitis in ICU patients. Case 7: After 4 weeks of prodromi a 37-year-old woman was admitted because of ketoacidotic coma as first manifestation of diabetes mellitus. As sign of the preexisting diabetes, hemoglobin Alc was elevated up to 12%; pancreas enzymes were in the normal range. The course was complicated by pneumonia, sepsis and DIC. Atthough there were no abdominal symptoms, serum lipase increased up to 4926 U/L CT revealed subtotal pancreatic necrosis. Case 2: In spite of cesarean section a 24-year-old woman devetopped complicated HELLP syndrome (H=hemolysis; EL=elevated liver enzymes; Lp=low ptatetets).

Although there was significant improvement after starting treatment with plasmasmapheresis and prostacyclin, the patient developped fever of unknown odgin and raised consumption of insulin under parentera! nutrition. There were no abdominal symptoms, and serum lipase was in the normal range (t97 U/I). However, ultrasound demonstrated extended necrotizing pancreatitis. Case 3: A 24-year-old woman with pre-existing M.Crohn and chronic renal failure was admitted because of thrombosis of the right V.femoralis. Under treatment with fulldose heparin the thrombosis was progressive into the V. cava. The patient refused a V. cava filter and underwent coumarin anticoagulation. Without abdominal symptoms the patient developped moderate increase of lipase (575 U/I) with amylase in the normal range (32 U/l). CT revealed bleeding into the duodenal wall with obstruction of the papilla and consecutive pancreatitis.

Conclusions: 1 .) The above-mentioned rare causes of pancreatitis are important in tCU-patients who develop "secondary" pancreatitis. 2.) In these -partially unconscious and parenteratly nourished -patients abdominal symptoms and enzyme changes can be unreliabel. 3.) "}ndirect" signs can be decisive for the diagnosis of "secondary" pancreatitis: fever of unknown odgin, hypocalcemia, hyperglycemia, raised consumption of insulin and elevation of LDH. 4.) Sufficient therapy of the causal disease is crucial for the prognosis. To ascertain the long term outcome of patients who had angioplasty on the same admission as an uncomplicated acute non-Q wave myocardial infarction.

Patients and methods: Forty-seven consecutive patients underwent coronary angioplasty for this indication; the procedure was performed on 61 lesions, a median of six days post-myocardial infarction. Data on patients was collected on an on-line dedicated database at the time of coronary angioplasty. Mean age was 57 years, 77% were male. Thrombolytic therapy had been administered in 81% of cases, Information on follow-up (mean 15 months, 100% follow-up) was achieved by questionnaire, analysed by a clinician and vedfied by case note inspection.

Results: There were no acute complications at procedure in this group of stabilised patients. The success rate was 97%. During the follow-up period, all patients were contacted and detailed information about wellbeing was collected. There were no reported deaths. Restenosis of the target lesion was documented in 13 patients (27.7%); 9 patients had repeat angioplasty and 4 had elective coronary bypass grafting.

These results show that in acute non-Q wave myocardial infarction, coronary angioplasty can be performed on the same admission with a high success rate and low rate of clinical endpoints over follow-up, although patients should be aware that further procedures may be necessary because of restenosis. The overall outcome compares favourably with uncomplicated non-Q wave myocardial infarction treated medically. A prospective, randomised trial is still indicated to compare medical therapy with coronary angioplasty in patients with acute non-Q wave myocardial infarction.

tteparin associated thrombocytopenia (HAT) occurs in up to 5% of heparin treated patients; rarely it is associated with severe thrombocytopenia and additional venous and/or arterial thrombosis (HATT) and a life threatening course. Arterial thrombosis in this setting may be unexpected and clinical detection difficult. Case report: A 61 year old female patient was initially treated for acute anterior wall infarction by successful acute PTCA under high dose heparin therapy. She developed first signs of right sided deep vein thrombosis (DVT) twelve days later confirmed by phlebography despite effective i.v. heparin. Platelct count dropped from initially 250,000 to 85,000 on day nine. Treatment regimen was changed to tow molecular weight (LMW) heparin and platelet count increased to normal levels. Despite this therapy she developed left sided DVT. CT scan revealed extensive thrombosis of the inferior vena cava, left sided pulmonary embolism and thrombi in the aortic arch, descending aorta and abdominal aorta. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) confirmed these findings. Control TEE 24 hours later after application of heparinoid instead of LMW heparin, lg/kg immunglobulin i.v. and a treatment regimen with 100rag of front loaded rt-PA revealed a further increase of the arterial thrombotic masses. The patient died 24 hours later. Clinical diagnosis of FL&TT was confirmed by a positive heparin induced platelet activation assay with erossreactivity to LMW heparin but not to heparinoid. Conclusion: HATT is a rare but severe and life threatening complication of routine heparin treatment. Progression of the disease occurs with LMW heparin due to crossreactivity despite normalisation of platelet counts. TEE is an easily applicable method for the detection of clinical silent arterial thrombosis and should be used extensively for early identification of this severe complication of HATT.

body_text.text: In 3 patients (pt #1: female, CAD, EF 18%; pt#2: male, CAD, EF 47%; pt#3: female; CM, EF 60%) with frequently recurrent VT, EAAP (Ramp stimulation, 3-10 stimuli, coupling interval 81% of the tachycardia cycle length) delivered by an external device (Ventak PRx 1700, CPI) via a transjugular quadripolar electrode catheter was investigated during intensive care treatment. Definitive antiarrhythmic treatment had to be postponed as all patients were septic and mechanically ventilated at the time of the study.

Results: Using EAAP, termination of the spontaneous VT was achieved in 1462 of 1523 episodes (96%), acceleration occurred in 7 episodes (0,5%), and manual overdrive pacing or external cardioversion after failure of EAAP was necessary in 54 episodes (3,5%). A mean of 1,8_+0,5 attempts were used by the device until termination of the tachycardias. EAAP had to be used for 4, 21 and 15 days, respectively. One patient died due to hemodynamic failure. Two patients recieved catheter ablation and an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator and were discharged after 53 and 29 days, respectively. Because of echocardiographic signs of pulmonary hypertension and results of scintigraphy thrombolysis was performed instead of surgical embolectomy.

Results: Thrombolytic therapy with 100 mg of r-tpa and 1500 U/h of heparin was administered intravenously. 24 hours after thrombolysis, the right atrial thrombus had dissolved. Echocardiographic signs of right ventricular failure and pulmonary hypertension had disappeared. Scintigraphy showed partial resolution of perfusion defects.

Conclusion: Thrombolysis in patients with floating cardiac thrombi and pulmonary embolism may be an alternative to surgical embolectomy especially in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to multiple peripheral emboli.

body_text.text: STUDY OBJECTIVE: To assess the influence of social factors on short and long-term survival of patients admitted with acute myocardial infarction. DESIGN: Prospective cohort study. SETTING: Six general intensive Care Units (ICUs) from the Public Health Network of the Spanish region of Valencia. PATIENTS: A total of 380 consecutive intensive care patients admitted with the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction were followed for a median time of 3.4 years. The follow-up was complete in 96.1% of the patients. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: Most of the social factors considered in the study (educational level, marital status, employment status, income level, availability of car) were associated with short and/or long-terra prognosis in the crude analysis. After adjusting for main biological covariates (age, sex, Killip class, previous infarction and physical activity prior to admission) using Cox regression analysis, the social risk factors that showed an independently association with survival during the acute phase were a low degree of environmental confidence (adjusted relative risk = 1.82, 95%CI between 0.99 and 3.33) and to be never-married (adjusted relative risk = 2.09, 95%CI between 0.90 and 4.86). After the acute phase, the independent social prognostic factors were widowhood (adjusted relative risk = 2.17, 95%CI between 1.07 and 4.42) and the absence of a physician other than those in the ICUs that showed personal interest in the patient during his/her initial hospitalization (adjusted relative risk = 2.52, 95%CI between 1.01 and 6.25). CONCLUSIONS: Our study stresses the prognostic role of psycho-social factors of myocardial infarct patients. The prognostic importance of these factors may be different during the early and late period of the infarction.

La~"gner, Introduction :The diagnosis and management of wide-complex tachycardia (WCT) is often difficult in emergency situations. We studied the effects of adenosine, which offers new aspects of antiarrhytmic treatment in patients with WCT. Methods: Hemodynamically stable patients with WCT first underwent vagal maneuvers, if unsuccessfully, adenosine was administered in incremental bolus doses of 6, 12 and 18 mg every 2 minutes until sinus rhythm (SR) or transient atrioventricular (AV) block, unmasking the underlying rhythm, was recorded. In the latter and in the non-responding cases other antiarrhythmics were applied. Results:This study includes 35 episodes of WCT (QRS>0.12) in 19 patients (1 lmale, 8 female) between 23 and 83 years of age (mean 48 years). Adenosine terminated WCT and restituted SR in 19 of 35 episodes (54%). A short lasting AV block after adenosine in 3 episodes (9%) revealed atrial flutter in two cases and atrial fibrillation in one case as the underlying mechanism. In 13 episodes (37%) no effect after adenosine administration could be observed. The onset of adenosine effect was rapid and within 25 sec, the duration of ventricular asystole 2.5 +_ 1.1 sec. We observed known, short lasting adverse effects like palpitations, chest pain and flush, but no hemodynamical deterioration after adenosine administration. Conclusion: Adenosine terminated WCT in 54 % of all episodes. In the remaining cases it was able to disclose the type of arrhythmia and help find the diagnosis. Due to these results, we use adenosine as the agent of first choice for wide-complex tachycardia. J.E. de La Coussaye, J.J Eledjam. Overall, 897 patients were admitted to our tCU throughout the study period. Although the number of infected patients was relatively small in the colonized and noncolonized group of subjects respectively, the rate of infection was markedly higher in the colonized group, the difference being statistically significant (P<0.001) at chi-square test with Yates' correction. Comparison of hemodynamic tolerance of sequential haemodialysis (HD) and continuous haemofiltration (CAVH) during acute renal failure in ICU patients: randomized crossover study, B Misset, JF Timsit, B Renaud, J Cadet. Empirically, most intensivists are convinced that CAVH is better tolerated than HD, but this has never been demonstrated. The aim of this work was to compare the haemodynamic tolerance of the two methods, All the ICU mechanically ventilated patients who presented with acute renal failure between february 1990 and august 1993 were included and received CAVH during 24h and a 4h HD in a 24h period, between which was an intermediate "washout" period. The order of the CAVH and HD periods was randomised. The mean arterial pressure (MAP), was measured each 30mn. The mean MAP, the difference between the highest and lowest MAP and the proportion of MAP decreases >10mmHg were compared between CAVIl and HD periods. In addition, in order to take into account the associated treatments (weight variation and use of vasoconstrictive drugs), 9 physicians were asked to give a global judgment on the best tolerated method, looking at the haemodynamic and therapeutic data in a blind fashion. Results: 39 patients were randomised, of which 12 were then excluded (11 deaths before 96h and one technical failure). The 27 included patients were on 15 times HFAV-HD and on 12 times HD-HFAV. Associated pathologies with ARF were: cardiac or aortic surgery (n=10), infection (n=7), cardiac insufficiency (n=5), miscellaneous (n=5). Age=62_+16, SAPS at day0=16-+5, mortality=37%. The mean metabolic values and SAPS before the period, the efficacy of epuration, the mean weight loss I24h and the amount of vasocenstrictive drugs are identical for HD and CAVH. The best tolerated method, from the blind analysis of lhe MAP curves is CAVH in 60% of the patients and HD in 40% (not significant).

Tomoki Nishiyama, Masaki Nagase, Yoshihisa Tamai and Shinichi Watanabe Midazolaro is frequently used to attain continuous sedation in intensive care field. Its administration to hemo~tialysis(HD)patients is also popu!ar. HD affects various drug levels in the blood, however, the effects of HD on blood rnidazolam levels has rarely been reported. Two patients received a total of 6 HD sessions and their blood midazolam levels were determined before and after HD's. The results are reported in the present study.

Methods: The first patient was a 42-year-old male. He underwent HD because of acute renal failure(ARF)due to crush syndrome. He withdrew from HD after 17 sessions and showed satisfactory results from treatment, The second patient was a 26-year-old male who suffered from ARF and hepatic insufficiency after the emergency operation for crushed lungs and hepatorrhexis. Unfortunately the patient died although we performed 16 HD sessions and 2 sessions of plasma exchange. Both of these two patients received continuous intravenous injection of midazolam for sedation during artificial ventilation. Blood midazolam levels were determined four times; before HD, during HD, (after HD)arld on the next morning.
l%esults: Blood midazolam level during HD was higher than that before HD. The concentration increased and reached its peak at the end of HD sessions and decreased on the next morning.

Discussion: Midazolam does not penetrate through dialyzer because 96-97 percent of midazolam is bound to protein in the blood. HD removed water from plasma and blood midazolam level increased. Intracerebral midazolam concentration immediately reaches the level parallel to the blood level Therefore, this possibly suggests that the effects of midazolam might be enhanced during HD.

Conclusion: Blood mJdazolam levels of HD patients who were sedated by its continuous intravenous injection were determined before and after HD. Midazolam effects might be enhanced during HD because of the increase of blood midazolam level.

The monitoring of the oxygen partial pressure in bIood is an essential field in biomedical engineering. For this application, an electrochemical Og-sensor using a smooth glassy carbon electrode has been developed.

Methods : Two different potential levels of preset durations were imposed on the sensing electrode in a cyclic manner. The current flow due to Og-reduction at a negative potential is integrated after a time lag. The charge is proportional to the oxygen concentration. The electrode is then held at a positive potential for a longer period before repeating the cycle. Thus, oxygen is consumed only during the short pulse duration. The principle of this sensor is unique since the sensing electrode operates without a covering membrane, This is possible because of the low electrocatalytic activity of glassy carbon and the negligible protein adsorption on the smooth electrode surface.

Results : Measurements with the sensor in bovine serum demonstrated the minor influence of other physiological substances on the response to oxygen. The response is immediate and reproducible even at a low consumption of oxygen, in a first step the sensor was tested in animal experiments where it showed a.good response as well in biood as in tissue. A newly designed catheter type sensor was ne~ cUnicatly tested by implanting it in the vena famoralis d patients. The oxygen partial pressure was intermittently measured with this sensor over a period up to five days.

Discussion : The described sensor is suitable for implantation because of its biocompatible electrode material and low oxygen and energy consumption, The low cross sensitivity of the sensor towards other physiological substances is demonstrated by only minor changes of the measured oxygen values on changing from saline solution to whole blood or tissue. The obvious main advantages of this new oxygen sensor principle are the very short response time, no need of using a membrane, the very low energy consumption as a consequence of the pulsing method of measurement and the low oxygen consumption so that tissue is not damaged. Hence, by virtue of longterm oxygen sensing in blood, the pacing rate of cardiac pacemakers, for instance, can be adapted leading to the development of physiologically adapted or rate responsive cardiac pacemakers. However, it seems possible to use this sensor principle as a transducer for enzyme based sensors in many other applications.

Anamnestic, toxicologic and clinical presentation establishbd acute opiate intoxication in 14 patients. Arterial blood gas analysis (BGA), chest X-ray and clinical course were retrospectively analysed.

In twelve patients there was arterial acidosis (pH range: 7.16 to 7.37); partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO 2) was found above 45 mm Hg in ten patients. Four patients showed pronounced hypoxia (pC 2 below 60 mm Hg). Chest X-ray showed aspiration pneumonia in two cases and was compatible with pulmonary edema in one case. Nine patients showed pathological changes only in BGA, one only in chest X-ray and two in both examinations.

These data indicate the need for BGA and chest X-ray as a respiratory evaluation in cases of acute opiate intoxication even though these patients seem to be in clinically stable condition. Discharge should on]y be discussed after evaluating the BGA and chest X-ray results . Lithium is similar to sodium both from the chemical and metabolic point of view. In organism, lithium is not bound to proteins, does not metabolise and is eliminated almost exclusively by kidneys. These are the factors which make the toxicological effects of lithium different from those of other drugs, Lithium ranks among important drugs applied in psychiatry to affect[ve disorders. On a routine basis, lithium level is monitored in the course of treatment. However, lithium intoxications may be, though not frequently, encountered. The most frequent cases are associated with relative or absolute overdoses. Some intoxications are caused by suicidal overdoses. Toxicity signs occur regularly at lithium levels higher than 2 mmol/I. Levels higher than 3.5 mmol/I may be life threatening. 15% of lithium intoxications and 50% of suicidal cases are lethal. The central nervous system, kidneys and heart are the most affected organs. Severe lithium intoxications result in a refractory shock and multiple organ failure.

The treatment is based on ensurance and optimalization of vital functions and homeostasis, prevention and absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and the fastest possible elimination of absorbed lithium from the organism. Careful elimination is particularly important with the sustained-release lithium drugs. Gastric [avage is not sufficient, it has to be accompanied with gastroscopy combined with aspiration of the tablets under visual control, whole bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol lavage solution or with surgical removal of tablet mass, Hemodialysis, repeated in case of need, is the elimination method of choice with more severe lithium intoxications. Lithium elimination by urine can be enhanced by application of normal saline solutions and low doses of dopamine. Thiazides, furosemide and spironolactone are contra-indicated. Hemoperfusion is ineffective with intoxications by lithium; however, with intoxications combined with other drugs, particularly psychotherapeutical drugs, it may be useful.

In the course of intoxication, lithemia has to be monitored. Due to the pharmacokinetics of lithium, especially in case of the slow release drug, a multiphase course is to be taken into consideration. The initial stages of the intoxication may be underestimated by unexperienced doctors.

Incidence of septic complication was significanlty correlated with ICU stay (r=0,51, p<0,01) and ICU stay was longer in septic than in non-septic patients (10,8+4,6 vs 4,2+-4,7, p<0,01). Three out of 12 septic-patients died while no non-septic patients died (p<0,01). Serum lactate dosage could be used routinely at the time of admission in ICU to help in identifying patients with high risk of postoperative septic complications and perhaps preventing development of MOF.

However due to the advances in intensive care and the development of more effective and aggressive surgical anticancer therapy, intensive care in oncology has become even more important. Therefore it is necessary to reevaluate the role of intensive care in oncology. The hospital records of all patients admitted to the ICU of our hospital over a one year period (1.1.-31.12.1993) were reviewed. 511 admissions occured in 489 patients (m = 269, f = 220). The mean age was 57 years with 20 patients < 25 years and 34 patients > 75 years. Indications for intensive care in surgical oncology included postoperative recovery (458), complications of cancer and its treatment (21) and monitoring of aggressive anticancer therapy e. g. isolated limb peffusion (32). The mean duration of ICU stay was 6 days (max. 150d). Postoperative ventilation was necessary in 101 patients with a mean duration of 6 days (max. 94). Inotropic support and mechanical ventilation were more commonly required in non survivors. Reanimation was performed in 10 patients 6 of which subsequently died (60%), Overall 14 patients died on the ICU corresponding to a mortality rate of below 3%. However treatment related death occured in only 21% (sepsis, hemorrhage) of these patients while the others died of unrelated causes (lung embolus, myocardial infarction). Notably only 1 death oecured in the 32 patients admitted for monitoring of an investigative potentially toxic treatment. Interestingly autopsy revealed that clinical diagnosis of the immediate cause of death was correct in only 26% patients. Conclusively ICU-mortality of cancer patients in this specialized unit was comparable to patients with nonmalignant disease. There was no reliable predictive factor for survival, which enabled objective decisions about limitation of intensive therapy. In the future effective intensive care including specific monitoring techniques will play an important role for further development of anticaneer treatment.

Konrad, T. Schreiber, J. HNmel and M. Georgieff Some authors have shown that theophylline increases mucus transport in healthy subjects and patients with chronic bronchitis. However other investigators have found unconvincing or conflicting results. Therefore, we studied the influence of theophylline on bronchial mucus transport velocity (BTV) in ventilated patients. Methods.The study was approved by the ethics committee of our hospital. In a placebo-controlled double-blind study, the effect of therapeutic serum concentrations of theophylline on BTV in ventilated patients of a surgical ICU was investigated. Group 1 (n=10) served as controls and received placebo. The patients of group 2 (n=10) were given intravenous infusion of 5mg/kg theophylline over 20 rain, followed by lmg/kg per hour. Before administration of theophylline and lh after starting the infusion BTV, serum theophylline concentrations, and arterial blood gases were measured. Heart rate and blood pressure were registered every 5 rain. BTV was measured with albumin microspheres labeled with technetium-99m, which was deposited on the dorsal surface at the lower ends of the right and left main bronchi via a catheter placed in the inner channel of a bronchoscope.The movement was visualised and recorded using a scintillation camera. Results and Conclusions. The theophyllin treatment induced a significant improvement in BTV from 3.8 to 7.6 mm/min in the left main bronchus and from 0.5 to 5.4 mm/min in the right, while placebo was inactive. The increase in BTV, however, was associated with an increase in heart rate; in 3 patients the theophylline infusion had to be stopped because of severe tachycardia. Therefore routine application cannot be recommended but should be considered in risk patients (e.g. patients with chronic bronchitis and impaired tussive clearance).

Clinic for Anaesthesiology, University of Utm, Germany Abdominal aortic aneurysmectomy results in a general ischemiareperfusion syndrome, accompanied by an acute dse in mean pulmonary artery pressure (MPAP). Severe and sometimes fatal postoperative cardiopulmonary complications have been described, This study tests whether N-acetylcysteine (NAC), a precursor of the most important physiological antioxidant glutathione (reduced form GSH, oxidized form: GSSG), or the hydroxyl radical scavanger mannitol (MAN) modify these events. Patients received NAC 150 mg/kg (n = 8) 30 minutes before infrarenal aortic clamping or MAN 500 mglkg (n = 5) 10 minutes before declamping, 11 patients had no additional treatment (control). in the control group, we observed a significant increase in plasma levels of GSSG and lipid peroxides after declamping. There was an increase in MPAP to a peak of 27 + 4 mmHg and PVR to 156 + 26 dyn/s/cm-5/m 2. MPAP and PVR returned to normal values within 20 minutes. 6 hours after surgery, pulmonary dysfunction was manifest by increases in physiologic shunt from 8 + 2 % to 17 + 3 %, whereas pulmonary artery wedge pressure was in the normal range (13 + 3 mmHg) excluding a left venfricular failure. 30 minutes after declamping platelet levels had fallen to 110 + 20 and white blood cell levels (WBC) to 4.4 + 0.7. Both platelet and WBC returned to normals values but 24 hours after declamping the WBC was increased to 14.0 + 1.0.

Relative to the control group, NAC treatment led to a complete lack of changes in plasma GSSG and LPO values after declamping; there was a significant increase in the plasma GSH level The measured MPAP and PVR levels were unchanged. The expected pulmonary dysfunction was missed 6 hours after surgery. NAC minimized the decline in WBC 1o 6.0 + 0.7 and the postoperative increase to 11.5 + 0.8. MAN pretreatment had no effects on the parameters estimated in the acute phase after declamping; it minimized the changes in WBC (but not significant). Also, the pulmonary dysfunction was reduced 6 hours after surgery (from 8 + 2 % to 13 _+ 2 %).We conclude from the results, that NAC pretreatment is able to prevent the ischemia-reperfusion syndrome after abdominal aortic aneurysmectemy whereas MAN is mainly ineffective. Aim of the study was to compare the results of TD with a new non-invasive parameter reflecting cardiac output, the stroke distance (SD) of mitral valve (MV) and pulmonary venous (PV = left upper pulmonary vein) blood flow derived by pulsed Doppler transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), Study design: 27 patients were examined simultaneously with TD und TEE early postoperative after coronary artery bypass grafting. Stroke distance was defined as the product of VTI and heart rate. tin/rain] Significant correlation coefficients were found between MV-SD (r = 0,94; p < 0,01) as well as PV-SD (r = 0,89; p < 0,02) and cardiac output by means of TD in a linear regression analysis. Sch6nfelder, N.Doetsch, JC.Reidemeister Introduction: A wide range of sedative agents are used after cardiac surgery to optimise patients' situation and avoid vegetative dysregulation. The ideal agent does not exist, but the properties were closely met by gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHA). Methods: In this open randomised study of 66 patients undergoing CBG, the hemodynamical and sedative effects of three different analgosedative regimes were investigated. We administrated midazolam (M), propofol (P) and gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHA) for sedation. Boli of piritramid were used to provide analgesia. We noted the amount of analgetic drugs, time from the end of sedation until spontaneous breathing and extubation and the effects on gastrointestinal motility. Besides, a complete hemodynamical monitoring was performed by means of Swan-Ganz catheter and invasive arterial blood pressure measurement (HR, MAP, RAP, PAP, PCWP, CI, SVR, PVR) and serial blood samples were taken. Quality of sedation was estimated by Ramsay score. Results: The hemodynamical parameters, especially MAP and SVR were not influenced by GHA, but decreased in the beginning of administration of M and P. The duration of sedation was easily controllable during P and GHA, longer lasting during M. Shortest duration of postoperative mechanically ventilation we found in the P-group, followed by GHA. That time was significant prolonged after sedation with M. There was a good level of vigilance during P and GHA, worser during M. There was no influence on the gastrointestinal motility noted in P and GHA group, but restitution of gastrointestinal function was delayed in the M group. Furthermore, the need of analgetics was significant lower during sedation with P and GHA (30mg/15mg piritramid) than during M (75rag). Conclusions: Especially the physiological neurotransmitter GHA enables a sedation of high quality without any effects on the hemodynamical parameters and is therefore suitable for patients after cardiac surgery. Introduction: An increasing number of data indicates that cell-mediated immunity (CMI) is seriously impaired following open heart surgery (OHS). Objective of this prospective randomized study was to further delineate the mechanisms leading to these alterations. Patients and Methods: 20 patients (pts) formed control group A. 20 group B pts received 3x50 mg Indomethacin (lndo) from the first (dl) to the fourth postoperative day ((15) intravenously to block prostaglandin E2induced suppression of CMI response as well as 50 mg Thymopentin (TP-5) subcutaneously preop., on d2 and d4 to augment CMI reactivity. In vitro tests preop., on d] and d7 included measurements of the percentage of CD4+ T-helper (TH) cells, phytohemagglutinin (PHA)-induced synthesis of interleukin (IL)-2 as a cytokine primarily produced by TH1cells, and PHA-induced synthesis of IL-6 as a cytokine primarily produced by TH2-cells. Delayed type hypersensitivity (DTH) skin response to an antigen skin test battery and specific antibody (AB) production following tetanus vaccination preop and on d7 were used as in vivo tests for TH1and TH2-induced immune response respectively. Results: Postoperatively, group A pts showed a persistent significant reduction of CD4+ TH cells, IL-2/IL-6 ratio, and DTH skin response as compared to baseline values (BL), while AB production increased (p<0.05 vs.BL). In group B pts no change in CD4+ TH cells, IL-2/IL-6 ratio, or DTH skin response was observed (p<0.05 vs.group A), and postoperative AB production increased significantly (n.s. vs. group A). Conclnsions: 1.These results clearly indicate a significant suppression of TH1 induced CMI response following OHS, while TH2 induced response remains normal. 2.These alterations may gain clinical significance whenever a postoperative infection requires a TH1 response. 3.The suppression of TH1 response can be effectively counteracted by administration of Indo and TP-5.

body_text.text: Introduction: Commercial equipment dedicated to multichannel physiologic measurements is very expensive. Linking a personal computer (PC) to clinical monitors via RS-232C serial links lacks speed and flexibility in both setup and raw data processing. For bedside investigations, the device should be small, flexible in configuration, and allow for raw data transfer to PCs. We present a low cost solution for AT-type PCs. Methods: Disposable statham pressure transducers already in whitespread clinical use (DPT-2000, pvb, Kirchseeon, FRG) each are interfaced to the PC via a plug-in differential amplifier with integrated stabilized sensor voltage supply, and a common 16-channel analog-to-digital converter (A/D) board with 14 bit resolution (short slot). Custom software is written in PowerBasic (Spectra Publishing, USA). Results: The slope of the sensors is factory-adjusted. Stability is specified and excellent. By design, the gain of each amplifier is about 1200, and its frequency response is flat from zero to well above 3000 Hz. Zero-offset drift is negligible. The costs of the components of each amplifier are < 10 US$. The A/Dboard is standard at a cost of 200 US$. Maximum sampling rate is 1500/sec (386-SX, 16 MHz, 1 active channel) and inversely related to the number of active channels. Pressure resolution is 1/6 mm Hg, the range is 4-150 mm Hg. Data is stored on harddisk. Discussion: Zerooffset calibration is purely computational thus simplifying electronic circuitry. There is no need for range switching. The sampling rate can be varied according to individual demands, If anti-aliasing filtering was needed it could be easily incorporated. For purposes of longterm monitoring, an auto-sampling mode is provided with simultaneous sampling and data reduction. Dependent on the type of transducer used, monitoring is not restricted to pressures. The program performs well on a battery-powered laptop thus providing the required electrical insulation. Introduction: Postoperative PHT in patients with congenital heart disease is conventionally managed by hyperventilation, hyperoxygenation, alcalization and by intravenous infusion of vasodilating substances. Method; After conventional heart operation, comprehensive routine monitoring was installed including complete hemodynamic measurements and assessment of right ventricular function by transesophageal echocardiography. In two boys (1.7 and 5.2 years, both with trisomy 21 and repair of a complete AV-canal), no apparent decrease of PHT during NO-application could be observed, and the NO admixture was discontinued. We assesed 12 patients after successfull resuscitation and rewarming of accidental hypothermic arrest (group A) and 12 patients after induced hypothermic arrest during cardiac surgery (group B). The mean follow-up for the patients of both groups was in excess of 2 years. The following tests were performed: Brain MRi, EEG, doppler flow, neurologic and neurospsychological evaluation.

Cardiac arrest was signifacantly longer in group A (2,5 hours vs. 0,6 hours in group B; p < 0,02) but age was higher in group B (52 versus 44 years). The degree of maximal hypothermia was similar in both groups (mean 22,1°C in group A vs. 22,8°C in group B). Brain MRI showed one mild cerebellar atrophy and one focal posttraumatic lesion in group A. Whereas in group B 7 of 12 patients showed multiple brain emboli. Except for one trauma patient in group A no abnormalities beyond the normal limits by any of the performed tests were recorded. In group B however age and pathology -induced alterations could be found.

In conclusion after hypothermic cardiac arrest the above tests show a few changes in group A but more pathological brain lesions in group B. Considering the excellent results at follow-up of patients after accidental deep hypothermia and circulatory arrest we advocate a more aggressive policy to rewarm such patients with cardiopulmonary bypass.

In our unit, over a 6mouth period [may-ast] in 1991, seven renal transplant recipients developed PCP. This was a significant change from our past experience with this disease, since only 2 cases had been observed over the preceding 5-year period. All patients were HIVnegative. Since 1986 we have been using the same immunosuppressive protocoIs for renal transplantation. The seven patients received OKT3 for the first fourteen days associated with low-dose steroids and azathioprine, with a delayed introduction of cicinsporin in six patients. Acute graft rejection episodes were treated with three intravenous injections of methylprednisolone. No prophylaxis for PCP was used. All episodes of PCP were diagnosed by the presence of cysts of Pneumocystis carinii in broncbealvenlar lavage (LBA) specimens. PCP occurred 140 (41-578) days after renal transplantation. Six patients experienced 1 episode of acute rejection in 3 cases and 2 episodes in 3 cases. All patients were treated by trimethoprime-sulfamethoxaxole (TMX). Outcome was favorable in 5 cases, but 3 patients died from respiratory failure. When survivors were compared with non-survivors, differences were observed in Pa02 on admission (p<0.05) in serum LDH increase (p < 0,05), and in the use of mechanical ventilation (p<0.05). Cytomegalovirus co-infection was identified in 6 patients by isolation of the vires from blood and/or LBA. Four bacterial co-infections were also observed. After institution of routine prophylaxis with TMX, only one case of PCP has developed, in a patient who was not receiving adequate prophylaxis at the time PCP was diagnosed. In 1987 a new medical unit devoted to AIDS patients was located in the same building as our own unit. Each anit has its own medical staff, but RTR and HIV-infected patients, sometimes shared waiting rooms and some of the rooms used for various treatments including pertamidine aerosols. It is thus tempting to speculate that inter-human contamination could have been a cause of PCP, as suggested earlier in SwitzeNand and France. During the epidemic all infected RTR had been admitted in the transplant unit, with overlapping stays, and thus transmission of the disease between PCP RTR and non infected RTR could have been possible.

Meanwhile, pretreatment with SDD could markedly attenuate the increase of endotoxin concentrations in both portal and systemic blood (P<0.05-0.01), resulting in a reduction of the endotoxin levels of faecal supernatants to less than 0.5% of the untreated control. J.G.J.V. Aerts, B. van den Berg, J.M. Bogaard. Both Demand Flow ~F) and Continuous Flow (CF) CPAP systems are frequently used in patients weaning from mechanical ventilation. DF systems are considered to increase workload due to the mechanical characteristics of the valve-system. We studied the effects of a DF CPAP system on imposed Work Of Breathing OgOBcir) and total resistive WOB OVOBres) compared with a CF CPAP system. VANDERKELEN Pulmonary atelectasis is frequently encountered in critically ill patients, specially under artificial ventilation. Persistent atelectasis leading to hypoxemia and pulmonary infection needs particularly an aggressive therapeutic approach. Ten patients (8 smokers) developed under artificial ventilatory support persistent lobar atelectasis resistant to current treatments including antibiotics, mucolytics, aerosols and physiotherapy (vibration, suction, postural drainage ...). All these patients developed a clinical respiratory deterioration with diagnostic of a lobar atelectasis on chest roentgenogram. Repeated fiberoptic bronchoscopy was performed in all patients without definitive and complete resolution of the lobar atelectasis.Intrapulmonary percussive ventilation (IPV, delivered through a Volumetric Diffusive Respirator, combinated with a conventional ventilator) was applied every two hours leading in all cases to the normalisation of the pulmonary clinical and radiological status, within 8 hours after the first application of the high frequency percussions (100 to 400 cycles/rain). Tolerance was excellent in all patients; no side effects were noted. Sputum volume cleared after starting IPV was greater than before.This observation suggests that IPV can be a usefull therapeutic method to improve pulmonary drainage in intubated patients and to resolve persistent pulmonary atelectasis.Critical Care Departemem -CESM-Roy Military Hospital, Bmssets-Belgium VENO-ARTERIAL GRADIENT IN C02 IS NOT CORRELATED TO CARDIAC] INDEX IN SEVERE ARDS D. Therefore, the effect of surfactant therapy on established influenza A pneumonia in mice was tested. Methods: 40 male NMRI mice were randomly divided in 2 groups (n = 20). On day 0 of the experiment both groups were infected with aerosolized live influenza A virus (nebulized virus suspension HA titer 1:8) On day 5 after infection, group 1 received 100 1~1 intratracheally of a bovine surfactant suspension (t 0 mg/ml). Group 2 was sham treated with 100 tsl of Hepes buffer and served as controls. Deaths were recorded every 12 hours till day 12 after infection. Statistical analysis was performed with product limited survival estimates. Results: During the instillation of fluid on day 5 after infection, one animal died in the surfactant treated group. Survival in the surfactant treated group was significantly increased compared to the control animals; p = 0.0055 (log-rank) In the control group, all animals (n=20) died of influenza A pneumonia between day 7 and 12 after infection. In the surfactant treated group, only 10 animals died between days 8 and 12. On day 12 after infection, 45% of the animals in the surfactant treated group were alive versus 0% in the control group. Conclusion: The results show that surfactant treatment improves survival in influenza A infected mice. Surfactant instillation seems, therefore, a promising approach in the treatment of viral pneumonia. We investigated the predictive value of 5 scoring systems in neurosurgical ICU-patients with traumatic and nontraumatic disorders.Methods: Mortality Prediction Model(MPM, 2 versions: 'admission' and '24 h'  [2]), Simplified Acute Physiology ScoreSAPS [3]  and Acute Physiology And Chronic Health Evaluation5]) were calculated in 93 patients conseeutively~ The diagnoses were: intracranial tumor (33 pts.), intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage (26), head trauma (25), others (9). Spiss Introduction : External ventriculostomy for drainage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or intracranial pressure (iCP) measurement is frequently used in ICU-Patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage, trauma and a variety of intracranial diseases. Intracranial infection related to this technique has been found from 3.5% to 21.9 %. The treatment of catheter related ventriculitis includes change of the catheter and systemic as well as intraventricular antibiotic treatment. The aim of the study was to evaluate the predictive value of standard laboratory examinations for the diagnosis of bactedotogically documented CSF infection. the time of ventriculostomy or because of other indications. Daily CSF samples were obtained and examined for cellcount, total protein concentration, glucose concentration and bacteriological culture. Student t-test and Fisher exact test were performed. Results : The ventricular catheter was in place from 1 to 25 days. 38 Positive CSF bacteriological cultures were found ( the most frequent germs : Staph. epidermid., Staph. aureus). No significant relationship between drainage time and positive CSF culture was found. The only parameter significantly correlated with the result of the bacteriological study was the CSF cell-count (unpaired t-test, p<O.05). Conclusion : Despite a preceding surgical intervention as an influencing factor for CSF pleocytosis the CSF cell-count remains the most valuable parameter of a catheter related infection.
