TABREF219.text: Patients with VSR who did tolerate a delayed surgical procedure were typically without posterior wall infarction, severe tricuspid regurgitation, haemodynamically stable on inotropic drugs, vasodilators and aortic pump, had a smaller shunt flow, and were not artificially ventilated, Our preliminary data on their probable distinguishing characteristics need further confirmation in a larger group for a clinical application.Center for Intensive Internal Medicine, Medical Center Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia, LONG-TERM USE OF AMINOSTEROIDAL NEUROMUSCULAR BLOCKING DRUGS IN THE INTENSIVE CARE UNIT H.J.Sparr, K.S.KhuenI-Brady, F.K.P0hringer, A.Pomaroli, M.Seyr, W.Hasibeder, S.Agoston INTRODUCTION:The long-term use neuromuscular blocking drugs (NMBD) in critically ill patients may be complicated by prolonged paralysis of peripheral muscles. The incidence seems to be related to both to the duration of administration and the total dose of the NMBD. Although, NMBD are widely used in the ICU, well documented dose recommendations in the critically ill patients are still lacking. The aim of the study was to determine the dose requirements of various aminosteroidal NMBD in the ICU. METHODS: This was a prospective, open clinical study in patients admitted to the intensive care unit with conditions necessitating mechanical ventilation for at least 48 hours. Postoperative intensive care, ventilamry support and anatgo-sedation provide a major contribution to securing the therapeutic success after abdomino-thoracic resection of the esophagus. Since June 1990 an analgo-sedation with clonidin is employed in the post-operative management after esophagus resection. Clonidin dosage is varied according to heart rate. The efficiency of this approach was evaluated by comparing the current.treatment to a historic group of patients without clonidin. Method~: 142 consecutive patients (1990) (1991) (1992) (1993) after abdomino-thuracic resection of the esophagus received clonidin (group A), whereas 45 patients (1988) (1989) (1990) were treated without clonidin (group B). Patients in group A were treated with a continuous infusion of clonidin at a rate of 1 to 4 mcg/kg/hr and of fentanyl at a rate of 0.5 to 10 mcg/kg/hr compared to group B with a continuous infusion of fentanyl and midazolam at 0.5 to 6 mcg/kg/l~ and 50 to 500 mcg/kg/hr respectively. All patients in group A were ventilated in pressure-controlled or BIPAP mode, in group B in volume-controlled or also pressure-controlled mode. Target criteria were overall letality, duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay on the ICU, cumulative dosage of sedatives and rate of p~flmonary complications. Results: Both groups, though different in size, showed no significant differences in demographic data, surgical procedure and preoperative risk factors. Overall letality was reduced from 36% in group B to 4% in group A, as was the frequency of pulmonary complications from 56% to 12%. Patients in group A could be extubated much earlier (average lime of ventilation 54 hr vs. 96 hr in group B). The LOS on the ICU dropped from 18 days to 6,5 days and daily average dosage of midazolam could be reduced from 200 mg in group B to 0-20 mg in group A. Conclusion: In this investigation the additional application of clonidin for analgosedation and the exclusive use of pressure-controlled ventilation lead to a significant reduction of letality and morbidity after abdomino-thoracic resection of the esophagus. Our experience shows that even in the elderly patient major surgery including two cavity operations is feasible with an overall letality below 5% in a combined approach of optimized surgical technique and a differentiated post-operative intensive care. In the present study, the dynamics of oxygen consumption (VO2) and carbon dioxide production (VCO2) during the rewarming period were evaluated by continuous measured metabolic gas exchange in 30 patients subjected to scheduled major surgery. During the rewarming period (from 35.0 + 0.98 to 37.5 _+ 0.70 ° C) VO2 increased by 34 + 32 % and VCO2 by 42 + 32 % (both p<0.0001). The majority of the patients (70 %) either showed a gradual increase in VO2 up to a steady state level, with or without a proceeding peak probably as a consequence of shivering. In two of the patients, no steady state phase was achieved while 23 % of the patients showed a blunted rise in VO2. The two last patterns were related to prolonged length of stay in the tCU and increased therapeutic interventions implying postoperative complications (both p<0.05). The length of the rewarming period was increased (p<0.03) and the rise in VO2 was reduced (p<0.03) in the two patients who later expired. The length of the rewarming period was furthermore related to the severity of illness (r=0.47, p<0.03). Conclusion: Different patterns of VO2 and VCO2 during the rewarming period following major surgery was found being related to postoperative complications and to survical.Depts of Medicine, Uppsala and Anaesthsia, G~ivle,Sweden.

Since intestinal oxygen supply is often decreased in critically ill patients, we were wondering, if enhancement of intestinal motility may worsen tissue oxygenation in the bowel by increased oxygen demand. Methods: Twenty critically ill patients following open heart surgery were enrolled in the study. They were randomized to receive 4x20ml Cisapride (Cisa-group) or NaC1 0.9% (NaCl-group) via gastric tube. During a study period of 96 hours gastral oxygenation was monitored indirectly by determination of the gastral mucosal pH (phi) via tonometry. Results: In both groups phi dropped significantly 96 hrs. after admission to the ICU. A reflux of gastric content was present within the first 72 hours in the NaCl-group, while it occurred only on the first day in the Cisa-group. Reidemeister lmroduction: After cardiac surgery it is one of the main aims of postoperative intensive care to protect the myocardium and to avoid all hemodynamical changes that may increase oxygen consumption. Besides, it is important to prevent the almost pre-existing heart insufficiency from worsening. Methods: In an open pilot study we assessed the acute hemodynamical effects of intravenous (iv) ACE-Inhibitor (ACE-I) in 10 patients with anamnestic known arterial hypertension after coronary bypass grafting (CBG). Beside an hemodynamical monitoring (Swan-Ganz catheter, invasive arterial blood pressure measurement), we demonstrated the effects in the transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). All patients got 1,25 mg ACE-I iv / 15 min. Sereal recordings were made after each 5 rain for the first 30 min and then every 30 rain for a total of 2 hrs post-dosing. The multiplane 5 MHz-probe of the TEE was intubated and the gastric view was recorded on videotape until the therapeutic effect of the iv ACE-I. Results: A rapid onset of action was observed with changes being evident during the first 8-12 min following drug administration. Under ACE-I the MAP decreased from 126 (+_ 15) to 94 C~ 9) mmHg. RAP, PAP and PCWP decreased on an average of 27%, 1t % and 35%. CI increased on anaverage of 22%, whereas TPR and PVR decreased about 35% respectively 22%. There was no reactive tachycardia noted in any patient. By TEE we could demonstrate an obvious improvement of the global left ventricular (LV) wall motion attended by an increase of the LV-ejection and LV-shortening fraction. Conclusions: Oral ACE-I have an established place in the treatment of arterial hypertension. With Enalaprilhydrogenmaleat is now a good controlable iv ACE-I available for the physiological treatment of the arterial hypertension for avoidance of imminent myocardial ischemia because of increased afterload. The flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope (FFB) is a valuable tool for difficult airway management in anesthesia and critical care areas, As with any other procedure, the potential for failure may be minimized by adequate training. We therefore initiated a structured teaching program which includes fiberoptic nasotracheal (NT) intubation in anesthetized patients and developed a simple technique for continued ventilation. Methods. Forty consenting patients (scheduled for maxillofacial surgery, with obvious pathology suggesting difficult NT intubation) were enrolled in this study. Following 3 rnin preoxygenation, anesthesia was induced with fentanyl, continuous infusion and a supplemental bolus of propofol, and (after assuring ease of mask ventilation) vecumnium. Flexometallic tubes (usually a Mallinckrodi 6.0 and 7,5 mm ID) were inserted through both nares into the naso/oropharynx. A skilled assistant applied a jaw thrust, plugged airway leakages by hand, and continued manual ventilation with oxygen after connecting the smaller tube with the circle system. The FFB (Olympus LF-2, using a video system as teaching aid) was then advanced through the larger tube. FFB intrumcntation was started by one of the trainee residents; if he/she failed to enter and identify the trachea within 5 rain, the supervising instructor completed the intubation. Results. All NT intubations were performed by the residents within the time limit; mean duration of the procedure (from the beginning of tube insertion until midlrachcal positioning of the NT tube) was 185 s (range, 110 to 280). At entry of the FFB into the trachea, the arterial carbon dioxide tension averaged 35.9 mm Hg (range, 28.1 to 44.6) and the arterial oxygen saturation leveled between 98.4 and 99.9 percent. Conclusions. Maintenance of normocapnia and oxygen saturation provided a nou-stressful environment for teaching fiberoptic NT intubation. The unimpeded maneuverability of the FFB was favorable to gain experience and qualification for the next educational step of awake NT/orotracheal intubation techniques. Introduction. Measurements of thermodilution cardiac output, arterial and mixed-venous oxygen saturation, hemoglobin, and plasma lactate were performed at 9 defined time points during premedication (stages 1-3), anesthetic induction (4-6), and maintenance of anesthesia (7-9). DO21 and oxygen uptake (VO=I) were calculated from standard formulas. Regression analysis was used to determine the critical DO=I from the inflection point of the DOzI/VOzl regression. Results. back_matter.text: The continous monitoring of blood-flow is of special interest in transplantation surgery. Early diagnosis of detrimental postoperative complications like arterial thrombosis, acute rejection and low perfusion of the graft is not possible with conventio~ll techniques. In this studio a newly developed implantable Doppler ultrasound probe has been tested. An autofocusing ultrasound beam allows to register quick, safe and reproducible signals. The accuracy of the method has been proved with a circulation model. Flow data are absolute numbers, besides parameters of the perioperative monitoring like arterial blood pressure, central venous pressure, pulmonary arterial pressure and heart frequency are put into relation by computer processor. The time for implantation and calibration of the probes was about 10 min. So far no probe related complications have been observed. A vasospasm of thehepatic artery was seen in all patients after liver transplantation with a mean time of 16.06 h (SD.+/-11.81). An increase in blood supply was observed with a mean resistive index (R1) of 0.99 +/-0.31, mean pulsatilly index 0aI) of 2.5 +/-1.85 and mean hepatic blood flow index (HBVI) of 0.46 +/-0.12 on PODI. The mean flow was 4.2 ml/min (SD, +/-0.8) in the A hepatica and 9.8 ml/rain (SD. +/-1.5) in the V.portae. There was a significant increase in blood supply to the liver graft between POD 1 and POD 5. Different vasomotoric type of reaction was observed in either rejection episodes or hepatic failure due to prolonged preservation time.We conclude that graft monitoring with implantable Doppler probes is 8 safe and reliable method after liver transplantation to continously register graft perfusion. Giordano.Because of the shortage of organ donors, when a potential donor heart is defined "functionally inadequate", it has to be aggressively treated in order to recover it from acute but reversible conditions that could impair its function. Fulminant neurogenic pulmonary oedema [NPE] is a rare but dramatic process in young patients with massive, rapidly fatal brain damage. Moreover, NPE can acutely but reversibly hinder the performance of the heart considered for donation. Case Report. A ten years old girl with no history of cardiopathy, was admitted to our ICU because of deep coma due to massive spontaneous intracranial haemorrhage. The acute huge rise in intracranial pressure ( ICP ) was directly documented by ICP monitoring and indirectly reflected by the absent brain perfusion when angiography was performed. Following several hypertensive episodes [ mean systemic pressure (MBP) = 130 nun Hg ] associated with bradycardia [ heart rate (HR) 80 beat/min ], she became hypotensive (MBP = 60 mm Hg) and tachycardic ( FIR = 170 beat/rain ). Her electroencephalogram was flat and she was considered as a potential organ donor. The echocardiogmphy showed a marked global depression of cardiac function and its left ventricle ejection fraction (LVEF) was 0.20. Central venous pressure rose up from 5 to 18 man Hg, while arterial blood haemoglobin saturation ( SaO2 ) and oxygen partial pressure ( PaO2 ) fall down respectively from 100% to 70% and from 136 to 46 mm Hg, being the patient ventilated with the same air/O2 mixntre with FiO2 = 0.4. The chest X-ray was positive for acute pulmonary oedema and from the trachea it was aspirated abundant blood-tinged frothy fluid. Furosemide 20 mg and dobntamine (DBT) 37 mcg/Kg/min was administered i.v. while FiO2 was rised to 0.8; MBP became 75 mmHg, HR 140 heat/nlin and the urine output rose from 1-2 ml/h to 3-6 ml/h. Twenty' four hours later, SaO2 was 99% and PaOz was 100 mm Hg with FiO~= 0,3 and LVEF improved up to 0.5 with a DBT infusion rate of 18 mcg/Kg/min. The 12 hours procedures for brain death assessment was initiated. The weaning from DBT infusion was carried out and it was terminated before entering the operating room for organ excision. The heart was snccessfully implanted in a seven year old child after an ischemia of 135 minutes; the liver and the kidneys were also successfully implanted.Conclusion. The onset of NPE in brain-dead patients selected for organ donation, has to be considered; however, if promptly and aggressively treated, it does not contraindicates heart donation.Dept, of Anestesia and ICU 2 °. In the period January 1 till December 31 1993 organ donors were treated with a standardized treatment protocol (STP). Treatment started immediately after pronouncing brain death. Basic steps were: intensive monitoring, rehydration (colloid infusions), infection prevention and specific organ care. As a control group donors harvested during 1991-1992 were taken. Results. 47 donors were treated (STP group) and compalred with the control group (n = 74 The COLD system is an advanced hemodynamic monitoring system, which enaNes not onty measurement of right (COps) and left (COart) ventficutar output, but also of Cardiac Function Index (CFI), Intrathoracic Blood Volume (tTBV), Global Enddiastolic Volume (GEDV), Lung Water (ETV), Excretory Liver Function and Right Ventriculer Ejection Fraction (RVEF). Thus, it could be ideal for monitoring patier~ts (!0ts), which are bridged to transplantation by a left ventricular assist system (LVA8) like the Novacor. Between 2/92 and 1/94 10 pts underwent bridging to transplantation by the Novacor LVAS wearable system. In 4 pts a complete COLD monitoring was performed. Pts suffered from ischemic (l) and dilative cardiomyopathy (3)and were bddged between 4 snd 53 days. The COLD system was used for hemodynamic monitoring during and after implantation of the LVAS asd during and after heart transplantation (HTx). After injection of iced Indocyeninegreen (ICG) dye solution via a pulmonary artery cathether (PAC), the COLD system determines the above mentioned parameters. COpa and COart are measured using thermal dilution method, GEDV and ITBV are calculated by multiplication of COart with the mean transit time of the dye. ETV is determined by calculating the differences of the transit times of the indicators. ICG removal from blood takes place exclusively in the liver, thus the plasma disappearance rate (PDR) of the dye is a sensible marker for the excretory liver function. RVEF is determined using a common PAC, no fast response thermistor cethether is required. COpa and COart did show a significant improvement after LVAS implantation and HTx, as could be expected. Despite partially instable hemodynamic conditions during the perloperative period, estimation of COpe and COart was reliable and showed a good correlation (r=0.96) to calculated mechanical pump output. Measuring ITBV and GEDV enabled better management and control of the volume status, because these parameters are not influenced by intrathoraeic pressure as are central venous and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. Direct measurement of ETV proved to be superior to aesesment by lung x-ray, though in this two pts ETV did show an increase only initially after LVAS implantation and HTx. PDR fell shortly after implantation and HTx but did raise to normal values within the first three days. It showed a good correlation to liver blood chemistry, as an further advantage it is bedside available. Measurement of RVEF gives at any time an actual report about the performance of the right ventricle without the need of an expensive fast response PAC. The COLD-System proves to be a reliable monitoring system which offers additional parameters, that are of importance for an exact monitoring of LVAS patients.

One of the most hazardous complications after liver transplantation is vascular occlusion (10-20%), Early diagnosis and intervention is crucial for graft and patient survival. Duplex-sonography offers the chance for sensitive assessment of liver circulation and morphology with a minimum of risk for the patient. Duplex sonography was routinely performed on 25 liver transplants in 23 consecutive patients (9 male, 14 female) with a mean age of 42 years (range 4-65y). AII patients received a doppler and real-time ultrasound examination of the liver on the intensive care unit within 24 hours after transplantation and subsequently every second day using a transportable doppler unit (toshiba, sonIayer c% 3,5 MHz curved array). Additional examinations were performed if liver function tests took a suspicons course. Routine duplex ultrasound established the diagnosis of hepatic artery thrombosis in 6 of the 25 transplants 4 of which occured within the first 5 days after transplantation. Subsequent arteriograpy confirmed the diagnosis in all 6 cases and revealed the nature of vascular occlusion ( 3 dissections, 2 stenosis, 2 kinkings). Emergency operative revascularization resulted in 84% graft survival, while two patients died after retransplantation and no further therapy respectively. Only in 1 patient duplex-sonography failed to establish a relevant partial stenosis of the hepatic artery ( sensitivity 86%) while no false positive result occured in 123 examinations (specifity 100%). There was no correlation of the resistance index and acute rejection which has been suggested in renal transplantation. Real time examination revealed intrahepatic lesions in 5 cases (1 abcess, 4 hematoma) and 2 bilioma. In conclusion duplex sonography should be performed routinely in the early postoperative period after livertransplantation. This has major implications on therapeutic decisions and may obviate the need tot invasive procedures (biopsy, angiography) in these high risk patients.Dept. of Surgery, University of Heidelberg, Germany The effect of preoperative anticoagulant therapy on perioperative bloodless and changes in the hemostatic system after heart transplantation was examined in a retrospective study including 36 patients, ii patients (group H) received intravenous heparin preoperatively; 12 patients (group P) were transplanted under full phenprosoumon medication; 13 patients with no anticoagulation who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (group C) comprised the control group. In group H, intraoperative use of homologous red blood cells was increased (group H: 463±280, group P: 200±321 ml, group C: 46±i12 ml; p<0.05 vs group C) and 36hours postoperative chest tube drainage was highest (930_+670 ml) as compared to group P (580_+383 ml) and group C (416~286 ml); p<0.05 vs group C. The increase in activated clotting time after heparinization for cardiopulmonary bypass was leas£ pronounced in group H (461±95 seconds) as compared to all other groups (group P: 1370~229 seconds; group C: 920±437 seconds); p<0.0025. To counteract the reduced coagulation, patients of group P received more units of platelets (1.5~2.7), frozen fresh plasma (3.8+_1.4; p<0.01), prothrombin complex concentrate (916±452 I.U.; p<0.05) and vitamin K (8.3+_9.3 ms; p<0.05) postoperatively, than patients in groups P and C. The data indicate, that heart transplantation is feasible under full phenprocoumon therapy without increase of perioperative bleeding complications. In additiont phenprocoumon medication seems to stabilize the hemostatic system perioperatively when compared to longterm preoperative heparin treatment. back_matter.text: Safety and efficacy of ambulatory pump-driven pharmacologic bridging by implantable catheter systems in patients awaiting heart transplantation Kramer L.*, Pacher R., Daneshwar H., Kranz A.*, R0dler S., Wutte M., Lenz K,*, Druml W.** Introduction: With increasing number of heart transplantation (HTX) candidates, limited donor organ supply and a current mortality rate of 20-40% of listed HTX candidates, aggressive management is required to maintain patients on ambulatory treatment while awaiting HTX. Efficacy of PGEI in heart failure has been demonstrated with increase in cardiac output secondary to combined pre-and afterload reduction. Moreover, in patients requiring i.v. inotropic support, additional PGE1 infusion resulted in further hemodynamie improvement. We evaluated ambulatory PGE1 and / or standard catecholamine infusion in reducing pro-HTX morbidity and mortality.Setting: University hospital, ICU of the eardiologie department. Patients: 30 consecutive HTX candidates (27 mate, 3 female, age 51+12 yrs), LVEF<20%, NYHA IV, refractory to conventional oral or Lv. medication, were studied.Methods: During invasive hemodynamic monitoring, PGE1 was started at 5ng/kg/min and stepwisely increased. Individual dosage (10-20 ng/kg/min) was established at 50% of maximal tolerated dose. Dobutamine and dopamine were given at 5 and 3 pg/kg/min, respectively. In case of positive response to therapy (de, ned as maintained 20 % increase in stroke volume index), impIantatien of a dual lumen hiekman catheter into the internal jugular vein was performed under local anesthesia. Subcutaneous tissue was tunnelled 20 -40 cm to maximize patient comfort and minimize infection rate. Infusates were delivered by battery-driven micropumps fixed at the patient's belt. Patients and relatives were instructed for catheter and micropump handling. Ambulatory controls were performed weekly until clinical stabilisatien, transplantation or death.Results: PGE1 alone was given to 14 (group A), PGE1 + catacholamines to 8 (group B), and catecholamines alone to 8 patients (group C). Within 6 months, 11 patients underwent HTX, 9 patients died. 10 patients are currently on the waiting list, 3 of them weaned from i.v. support. Overall mortality was 30% However, subgroup analysis revealed significant differences in mortality (group A : 21%, group B : 12.5%, group C : 62.5%, p<0.01, chi-square test.) Regarding catheter complications, 1 patient developed ventdcular fibrillation during insertion, in 2 patients the catheter was displaced and had to be exchanged. None of the patients developed severe infectious or thromboembolie complications that would have prevented HTX.Conclusion: Ce~inuous ambulatory PgE1 and/or cateehotamine therapy delivered by a long-term venous access (Hickmen catheter) is a safe and effective way to reduce pro-transplantation morbidity and mortality.
